pages.articlebody:
KATY Perry has allowed her fans a rare glimpse at her music before she made it big — in a trailer to her forthcoming documentary about her rise to stardom.

Katy, 27, is releasing the Justin Bieber-style film that charts her path to stardom â from church singer to global superstar.

And in our sneak peak at Part Of Me 3D we see video footage of Katy as a youngster, with blonde hair, strumming her guitar at a gig as well as clips from her California Dreams tour.

In the trailer, she told her fans: "The atmosphere I grew up in was 100 per cent Christian.

"I started singing in church and I never really had another plan."

Catch the trailer below.

The film also sees Katy discuss her brief marriage to Russell Brand.

Comic Russ filed for divorce in December 2011 after just 14 months after they tied the knot.

Katy has since been linked with Baptiste Giabiconi, while Russell is loved-up with Hungarian model Nikolett Barabas.

pages.headline: 'Joker' Keira must be having a laugh
pages.teaser: KEIRA Knightley looks just like Batman nemesis The Joker in Interview magazine shoot
pages.articlebody:
KEIRA Knightley looks spookily like Batman nemesis The Joker in a new shoot.

Sporting ghoulish white make-up, acres of eyeliner and a slash of red lippy, the star was almost unrecognisable in photos for Interview magazine.

In another moody shot, Keira, 27, pouts with a cigarette in her mouth and huge designer shades hiding her eyes.

She also wears a trendy leather jacket open to the waist in another picture.

Keira, posed for the shots to promote her latest movie, A Dangerous Method.

The Brit beauty stars as a sex-starved psychiatric patient with a taste for masochism in the controversial drama.

Of her shocking role, Keira says: "People liked the spanking an awful lot. But Iâm not quite sure.

"When we were in Venice, I didnât get asked about it once... But in England, it was pretty much the only thing I got asked about.

"Iâm not quite sure what that says about the English."

Hmm, that we show a healthy curiosity wherever possible?

Either way, spanks for the memories, Keira!

The latest issue of Interview is on sale from April 10.

pages.articlebody:
HARRY Styles is only just 18 but heâs already worried about ending up with a Bobby Charlton comb-over.

The One Direction singer is so desperate to keep his curly locks, heâs pulled back on plying it with product.

Harry said: âI am a little concerned I might go bald soon. It worries me it might fall out. I am just watching how much I put on it now.â

The admission could cost him a lucrative David Beckham-style Brylcreem contract.

Meanwhile, Zayn Malik could be tapped up to front an anti-smoking campaign â if they can convince him to quit the fags.

He was snapped having a crafty ciggie out of his hotel window before rehearsals for the Nickelodeon Kidsâ Choice Awards in LA on Saturday.

pages.subdeck: Baring the flesh ... Lauren Goodger's top rides up as she leaves bar after night on the tiles
pages.headline: The Only Sway Is Essex
pages.teaser: REALITY star looks worse for wear as she stumbles out of a bar on a drunken night out
pages.articlebody:
BLEARY-EYED Lauren Goodger looks worse for wear as she stumbles out of a bar with her top riding up.

The Only Way Is Essex beauty has only just got back from holiday in Miami. But she was clearly still in party mode during a weekend night out with pals to Nu Bar in Loughton.

Poor Lauren wonât be thrilled when she sees these pictures â sheâs already upset about her appearance in holiday snaps.

She told this weekâs New! magazine she had a great time abroad â but admitted she felt self-conscious in her bikini.

Lauren said: âI look overweight. I loved it but I absolutely hate the pictures.

"You know Iâm not over the moon about my weight but they were horrific. And I look miserable.â

Lauren feared that while on holiday her tight clothes made her look heavier than she is. But she appears to have made the same mistake again with Sunday nightâs spray-on jeans.

Describing her holiday clobber, she said: âMy outfit looks unflattering, like it doesnât fit me properly. I just looked dumpy.â

Now Lauren plans to get her bikini body in tip-top shape before her next holiday to Marbella. She said: âI want to really work on it now. I want to lose two stone. I want to be a size eight to ten. It knocks your confidence.â

Lauren admits that alcohol calms her when sheâs feeling insecure. She said: âIn a situation like on holiday, I have to have a few drinks. It relaxes me so I donât care.â

But while she and TOWIE co-star James âArgâ Argent struggle to get fit, sexy Amy Childs has no such doubts about her figure.

Amy said she loves her body so much that she wants to strip off and pose for Playboy. Thanks to a punishing regime for her new fitness DVD â Fit In 30 Days, which is out on Monday â Amy has shrunk to a sexy size six from size ten.

But the body-confident babe said she would only pose for the raunchy magazine when she was in her thirties. She said: âI wouldnât do nude, Iâve never done topless, but Iâd do a sexy shoot. When your career is over, get a million pounds. Perfect, done.â

Amy, who claims sheâs too busy for love, says sheâs always loved her figure â but is getting a second boob job.

She told New! magazine: âItâll be four years since my last one and they are proper sagging. I look at pictures now and I notice the difference. When I first had them done they were perfect but now theyâre down a bit.â

But she warned young girls that getting breast implants was not a decision to be taken lightly. She stressed: âJust donât rush into it, really go to the consultations.â

Amy also admitted she was worried about the procedure after model Danielle Lloyd was rushed to hospital when one of her implants exploded. The reality star added: âIâm more nervous the second time round. But I really want them done.â

She revealed she has exciting projects in the pipeline, including a new show based on Paris Hiltonâs The Simple Life, which sheâll star in with cousin Harry Derbidge.

Describing her workout release, she said: âItâs hard work, and you see me struggling â I canât do it easily. But if you motivate yourself youâll be able to do it. There are a lot of toning treatments. You can lose weight and really tone up.â

Amy, who found fame as a salon owner on TOWIE, also slammed the show for being fake. âIt needs its X factor back. It needs to look more natural and not so staged.â

pages.subdeck: Revelations ... Cheryl Cole
pages.headline: Cheryl Cole has a pop at Louis Walsh
pages.teaser: SINGER has accused X Factor judge of earning cash from the popular band by doing nothing
pages.articlebody:
CHERYL Cole has accused Louis Walsh of earning cash from her band by doing nothing.

The star said her former fellow X Factor judge â once manager of Girls Aloud â had âzero involvementâ with the girls.

She said: âWe never had management. Louis claimed to be our manager but he never did it.â

Louis was on the panel of ITV1 show Pop Stars: The Rivals where Cheryl joined Nadine Coyle, Kimberley Walsh, Sarah Harding and Nicola Roberts in 2002 and was billed at the time as their boss.

But Cheryl told Marie Claire magazine: âWe didnât talk to him or anything like that.

âHe just took a cheque. Oh yeah, he took the cheques.â

Cheryl also had a go at him for telling the girls they were fat. She said: âThe label sent us for training. We thought they were doing us a favour. We were so deluded.â

pages.subdeck: Drunken regrets ... EastEnders actress Jacqueline Jossa
pages.headline: Jacqueline Jossa’s EastBenders
pages.teaser: EASTENDERS actress has told how she has given up booze after her mum videoed her when she was drunk
pages.articlebody:
EASTENDER Jacqueline Jossa has told of her horror at being videoed by her mum when she was steaming drunk.

The actress, whose wildchild character Lauren Branning is currently embroiled in an alcohol abuse plot, has been so affected by the storyline that she has now given up the booze.

Jacqueline, 19, said: âI come from an Irish family so there are a few alcoholics inevitably.

âBut the story has completely changed the way I think about alcohol. Before we got started my mum filmed me when I was drunk and showed me the video afterwards. It was disgusting.

âThat helped with research though. I havenât drunk any alcohol for about six weeks, so itâs definitely affecting me.â Jacqueline revealed she had a novel way of playing drunk â getting dizzy.

She said: âThe best way to prepare is spin around loads. Youâd think it makes you want to crack up laughing on set, but I donât do it that much.â

pages.headline: Geri Halliwell is a TV Wannabe
pages.teaser: FORMER Spice Girl follows in the footsteps of bandmates Mel B and Emma Bunton by landing fly-on-the-wall show
pages.articlebody:
GERI Halliwell has become the latest Spice Girl to sign up for a reality TV show.

Ginger Spice is working on a new series for Sky Living and the cameras have already started following her around.

The top secret show sees Geri team up with her former bandmates to work on the Spice Girls musical.

It also focuses on her new beachwear range and is expected to provide an intriguing glimpse of the singerâs home life.

A source said: âGeri is keen to do some TV as sheâs seen the other girls doing bits and bobs.

âSky Living reckon she fits their female-skewed brand.

Geri is really excited about the project, which is at the very early stages.â

Geri is following in the footsteps of fellow Spices Emma Bunton, who was a judge on Dancing On Ice, and Mel B, who had her own fly-on-the-wall reality show.

Mum-of-one Geri is no stranger to being filmed for a real-life TV programme.

She famously appeared in a Channel 4 documentary, simply named Geri, which was made in 1999 shortly after she quit The Spice Girls.

pages.subdeck: Reunited ... Steps
pages.headline: Steps show is no Tragedy
pages.teaser: GROUP go down a storm with their fans at opening night of reunion tour
pages.articlebody:
STEPS have returned to the stage for the first time since 2001 - and they're still as camp as Christmas.

The reunited quintet were surrounded by scantily-clad backing dancers of both genders and made good use of their impressive props department on the first night of their come back tour.

Lisa Scott-Lee and Faye Tozer were keen to show off their slender pins in a series of eye-catching outfits, but Claire Richards opted for more conservative attire.

The singer recently revealed sheâs âproud to be a size 16â having piled on the pounds since the group first disbanded.

Her bandmate Lee Latchford-Evans, whoâs been plying his trade as a personal trainer in recent years, was reportedly concerned she wouldnât be fit enough to complete the groupâs Ultimate Tour.

Ian âHâ Watkins was in typically energetic form at the opening night in Belfast and donned a leather jacket emblazoned with the letter âHâ for the Odyssey Arena gig.

Despite sporting a few more wrinkles than they did in their late 90s heyday, the fivesome proved theyâre still an excitable bunch as they unleashed their cheesy dance routines and played with fire.

The Tragedy clan received rapturous applause from their fans, who have seemingly forgiven them for their controversial split.

Followers attacked the group after they threw in the towel on Boxing Day 2001, just weeks after releasing a greatest hits collection.

Fans claimed they had denied split rumours to capitalise on a host of merchandise put out in the lucrative pre-Christmas market, including their Gold collection.

However, they reformed last year and released new âbest ofâ disc The Ultimate Collection, performing again for the first time on This Morning on October 10.

Their Ultimate Tour sold out in minutes and six extra dates were added due to demand for tickets.

pages.headline: U2 drop cash into Dropbox
pages.teaser: SINGER Bono and guitarist The Edge invest money in internet storage firm
pages.articlebody:
U2 ROCKERS Bono and The Edge continue to build up their business portfolio with individual investments in Dropbox.

The Get On Your Boots stars â who made profits of Â£620million from their Facebook investment â have staked money in the fledgling internet storage firm.

The service described as âtechâs hottest start-upâ already has 50million users.

Itâs free for users who only use 2Gb to store documents, photos and video in the cloud. Heavy users are charged monthly.

Although the cash Bono and The Edge have stumped up remains undisclosed, the company tweeted: âDropbox is excited to welcome Bono & The Edge as investors.

âThanks for the support and look forward to great things!â

Itâs the latest in a recent spate of tech investments for U2 singer Bono, whoâs also poured money into Pal, Yelp and Facebook.

pages.subdeck: Next generation Beatles? ... (l-r) James McCartney, Sean Lennon, Dhani Harrison and Zak Starkey
pages.headline: Beatles boys to form Fab Four Jr?
pages.teaser: JAMES McCartney wants to form band with Ringo, George and John's sons
pages.articlebody:
PAUL McCartneyâs son has revealed The Beatlesâ kids are working on plans to form a band.

James is eager to team up with Sean Lennon, Dhani Harrison and Zak Starkey to create the next generation of the Fab Four.

However, he admits Ringo Starrâs son Zak is too busy to join â but his brother Jason, also a drummer, has expressed a keen interest.

He said: âI'd be up for it. Sean seemed to be into it, Dhani seemed to be into it. I'd be happy to do it.â

Asked if the group had been mooted, James replied: âYeah, a little bit.â

In a BBC interview, the singer/guitarist said he believes the dream could become a reality.

He added: âYeah, hopefully, naturally. I don't know, you'd have to wait and see.

âThe will of God, nature's support, I guess. So yeah, maybe.â

James, 34, has released three solo EPs to date and has worked with his famous father in the studio.

Like his dad, Dhani, 33, is a guitar player who completed Georgeâs final album Brainwashed following his death in 2001. He formed a band called thenewno2 in 2006.

Johnâs lad Sean, 36, is a singer, songwriter and guitarist who has released several solo and band albums, and has worked with his mum Yoko Ono.

Zak, 46, is the oldest and best known name of the clan, having drummed for Oasis and The Who.

pages.teaser: LLOYD CHRISTMAS is dusting off his orange tux as Dumb & Dumber sequel is confirmed
pages.articlebody:
LLOYD Christmas is dusting off his orange tux as the makers of Dumb & Dumber confirm a long-awaited sequel.

Days after the Anchorman and Twins comebacks were announced, director Peter Farrelly revealed Jim Carrey and Jeff Daniels have signed for the follow-up to the 1994 hit.

The film-maker said: âWeâve always wanted to do a sequel. Jeff always wanted to do it. We always wanted to do it. Jim was busy, but he called and said, âWeâve got to do this thing againâ.

âHeâd just watched Dumb & Dumber and he said, âThis is the perfect sequel. Letâs do it.ââ

Farrelly, who had nothing to do with the panned Dumb & Dumber: When Harry Met Lloyd, will begin shooting with brother BOB in September.

pages.subdeck: In it to win it ... (left to right) Tia, Courtney, Reo, baby Niyah and Ellie
pages.headline: All our cash goes on beauty pageants
pages.teaser: THE Woodall family, from Lincoln, spend their life in a whirl or hairspray and sequins
pages.articlebody:
THEIR lives are a whirl of hairspray, glitter, sequins and ribbons â yet the oldest of this family group of beauty contest hopefuls is still only 14.

In recent years five of the Woodall familyâs kids â Courtney, 14, Tia, eight, Ellie, seven, Reo, three, and one-year-old Niyah â have taken Britainâs child beauty pageant scene by storm.

Together with mum Leanne, grandma Joyce, dad James and 15-year-old big brother Josh in a supporting role, the Woodalls believe they are now the UKâs largest âpageant familyâ.

But the hobby doesnât come cheap â Leanne estimates that in nine months the family have spent over Â£5,000 on Tia alone.

And they are set to spend at least another Â£12,000 now that five of the kids are involved.

Every spare penny of Dadâs wage as a fork-lift truck driver funds the competitions.

Leanne, 32, says: âI love everything about pageants. I know itâs a controversial thing to get your kids involved in, but I think people read too much into it.

âTheir confidence has shot through the roof since theyâve started competing. Itâs wonderful watching my kids doing so well.

âThereâs such a buzz about the UK scene â itâs fresh and exciting. Itâs so rewarding being right at the forefront of it and Iâve never heard of as big a family as mine getting involved.â

Leanneâs obsession was sparked by seeing footage of American pageants and has escalated so much in the past 12 months that normal family life at their home in Lincoln has been put on hold.

She says: âThe glitz and glamour come at a high price. Youâre talking at least Â£500 to Â£600 per child per competition. Thereâs the entry fee plus travel expenses, costumes and grooming on top.

âThe dresses alone cost Â£300 to Â£400, and you canât wear them more than once.

âThe shoes cost up to Â£60 a pair.

âThen thereâs all the beauty, the hair, nails and tan.â

Evenings are spent searching YouTube for clips of the biggest and best pageant stars for inspiration.

Most nights after school the kids practise their choreography for the talent round and try out their hair and make-up.

Leanne says: âItâs the nature of the scene â to stay at the top, youâve got to keep going bigger.â

Grandma Joyce, 49, a former pub landlady, is a dab hand with a needle and has made countless âone-offâ outfits for the troupe.

Leanne says: âItâs so important to have good costumes. My mum is brilliant. Sheâs really talented at making fabulous costumes, so thankfully we donât have to buy them all.â

Every weekend, James, 29 â who is stepdad to the two eldest kids â looks after baby Niyah, while Leanne, Joyce, Tia, Courtney and Ellie check out shops nationwide to find fabrics and accessories.

Leanne says: âOur outgoings are sky-high. James and I have cut back so much. Weâve gone from taking two holidays a year to one and when we do go away we stay in the UK.

âWe donât eat out much any more and I buy my clothes from budget stores such as Primark and Asda so I can plough money back in to the kidsâ pageant wardrobe.â

The result of all their effort is a mantelpiece full of awards.

Leanne says: âThe kids are all naturals, especially Tia, who won the Tiny Miss North crown in her first ever competition. All my kids have the pageant bug â even my three-year-old son.â

This year the family are going even further, as Tia prepares to become the first British competitor in the Dream Girls USA pageant in St Louis, Missouri.

Leanne says: âIn Tiaâs last competition, she danced to Copacabana by Barry Manilow.

âSome people think the song is inappropriate for an eight-year-old but she doesnât understand the words. Itâs just a good beat to perform to.â

Recently Leanne and Joyce have found it hard to find the sort of bold, ostentatious outfits that they say are needed to stand out.

So they plan to launch their own online pageant boutique.

Leanne says: âMum made the showgirl costume for the Copacabana dance and it went down a storm.

âItâs really hard to find unique âwow-wearâ here and itâs expensive to ship it from the US.

âThis is an ideal opportunity to turn something we love into a business venture. Thereâs the market for it and it means that weâll stay right at the forefront of pageant fashion.â

The US pageant scene has been growing for decades and has received a lot of attention in the UK.

It was notorious US cable TV series Toddlers & Tiaras that first got full-time mum Leanne hooked.

She says: âWe would watch it as a family and Iâd be blown away by the glamour. Tia loved it too and was the natural leader.

âI think the other kids may have seen how much time I spent with Tia and felt a bit jealous. With six kids, thereâs always rivalry.â

Only 15-year-old Josh has opted to stay out of the spotlight, though he helps by babysitting during pageant season, from March to October.

Leanne is behind all of her kids when it comes to their pageant careers, but she insists she is realistic.

She says: âWe want to let them all dip their toe in and try it but I know itâs not for everyone.â

All the same, she wouldnât want to see the kids quit on a whim â especially Tia, who has had a flush of wins.

Leanne says: âWeâd never force her to do anything she didnât want. But weâd be reluctant to let her just walk away.

âSheâs so good and weâve invested so much.

âAlthough itâs not all about the winning, itâs a lot of money to spend if you donât succeed.â

Leanne dismisses the objections that are often levelled at pageants, insisting the outlandish outfits and make-up are harmless dressing up.

She adds: âKids wear less during the summer holidays on the streets in Blackpool.

âStrangers arenât going to walk off the street and see my kids in a swimsuit, because all the events are ticketed.

âAnd not every competition is full glitz. Theyâve all done great in natural pageants too.â

The Woodalls intend to keep following their pageant dream for as long as they can.

Leanne says: âI am so excited waiting for pageant season to get into full swing.

âWeâll all be spending loads of time together doing what we love most.â

myView



By Dr LINDA PAPADOPOULOS, Psychologist

THE notion of little girls enjoying dressing up is nothing new and there is nothing wrong with them role-playing.

What is concerning is that in competitions such as these, they are encouraged to experiment with themes they may not be ready to deal with.

These girls are being judged on their appearance. They are aware that to succeed they not only need to act a certain way but to look a certain way.

This is an unhealthy and potentially dangerous message.

We also need to consider the impact of wearing clothes that are designed to highlight sexual characteristics they do not yet possess.

Judging girls on how they look devalues them and teaches them to base their self-worth on being appealing to others. That is simply not fair to them.

Additional reporting: Naomi Rainey

pages.subdeck: Facing the facts ... Gemma Collins with and without make-up
pages.headline: Stars face the world just as nature intended
pages.teaser: WE ask TOWIE’s Gemma to follow in the footsteps of Fearne, Pammie and Dakota
pages.byline: By NIKKI WATKINS and CAROLINE McQUILLAN
pages.articlebody:
WOULD you rather endure a nerve-racking job interview than face the world slap-free?

If you answered Yes, you are one of more than two thirds of women who say they would be too scared to face the world without their make-up.

And a staggering 91 per cent of women would cancel a first date rather than turn up barefaced.

Despite this, a new craze has hit Twitter where girls are exposing their faces first thing in the morning.

And celebrities are now jumping on the bandwagon.

Over the last week Hollywood A-lister Dakota Fanning, presenter Fearne Cotton, actress Pamela Anderson and pop superstar Lady GaGa have been pictured without their usual war paint.

So to see how a confirmed glamourpuss feels without her armour of make-up, Sun Woman asked high-maintenance Towie star Gemma Collins to go au naturel.

Gemma, 31, admits make-up acts as a safety blanket and gives her confidence.

She says: âWhen I wake up in the morning I have an awful habit of looking in the mirror. I look and think, âOMG I am going to need three hours to sort this mess outâ.

âNo man could ever see me like that. Without make-up on, you get another Gemma. I just feel very, very vulnerable, too open.

âI even talk differently without make-up, softer than normal.

âWithout make-up you can really see what I am like as a person.

âMake-up is like wearing a suit to work â it makes you feel and act different. It changes me completely. I feel I can be more over the top with it on and make better decisions. Also, I feel protected.

âI can hide behind make-up if Iâm sad or feeling not so confident. The minute I get my eyes on and bronzer applied, I feel very confident.

âPast partners have preferred me with no make-up, even in the morning. But when a relationship is new I would always creep into the bathroom before a boyfriend woke up and put on some blusher, eye drops, white eyeliner and perfume so I looked fresh.â

âI would leave the house without make-up on, but only to walk the dog, go to the gym or pop to Tesco.

âBut I would not feel as confident in myself.â

And it has proved a huge hit since going on sale at Â£6.99 last week.

Now Superdrug bosses predict the Solait Dark Tan, whose effects were previously only available at beauty salons, will be the yearâs best-selling tan.

pages.subdeck: Expert ... UK's only 'pet astrologer' Fiona Celeste
pages.headline: Pet astrology ... it’s kitten in the stars
pages.teaser: THE UK’s only pet astrologer says we should be looking at our furry friends’ star signs
pages.articlebody:
MILLIONS of Brits check their own horoscopes every day â but the UKâs only pet astrologer reckons we should also be looking at our furry friendsâ star signs.

Fiona Celeste, 52, believes owners can get great insights into their petsâ behaviour from their zodiac chart.

The former air stewardess says: âI know some people think Iâm bonkers, but horoscopes are a great way for owners to get closer to their animals.

âYou can unlock a lot about your dog or catâs personality by looking to the horoscopes.â

Fiona, from Glasgow, has more than 100 critters on the books at her Celestial Paws business and charges Â£30 per pet for an âastrological interpretationâ.

The mum of three, who has been providing pet horoscopes since 2009 after switching from humans, adds: "It gives me a great sense of satisfaction to bring people closer to their animals.â

Here NIKKI WATKINS and JENNY FRANCIS ask Fiona to interpret 12 petsâ personalities from their star signs â and to describe how well they âmatchâ their ownersâ signs. Then the pet owners give their verdicts.

Aries

March 21 - April 20

LONG-HAIRED chihuahua Bo-Duppy is five years old and an Aries. His owner, teaching assistant Amy Barratt-Singh, 25, from Birmingham, is a Scorpio.

Fiona says: âThis confident and brave canine aims to protect and guard his family. From a young age you have been able to see early signs of his assertive, leadership potential. Sometimes this can come across to others as aggressive in style.

âHe is energetic and at times may well believe that heâs in charge.

âThere may be a power struggle between the signs of owner Amy and Bo-Duppy.â

Amy says: âBo-Duppy is certainly confident and brave. He is protective to the extreme and when we are in the street he will not let a stranger come anywhere near me.

âHe definitely shows leadership potential. He rules the roost in my house.â

Taurus

April 21 - May 21

LABRADOR Tumble, two, is a Taurus. He is owned by five-year-old Ben Watkins, from Tamworth, Staffs, who is a Libra.

Fiona says: âHis pup tends to have a calm attitude. He adores meal times but it has to be the leanest, finest and tastiest food available.

âWatch his weight, you donât want his beautiful appearance spoilt.

âA Libra and Taurus relationship should work very well as both signs are ruled by the planet of love.â

Ben says: âTumble is very greedy, so we do have to watch that he doesnât eat too much dog food, otherwise he will get fat.

âHe can get a bit excitable but normally he is quite calm and lets me lie and play on him. Really he is my best friend in the whole world.â

Gemini

May 22 - June 22

DAVE is nine months old, a miniature schnauzer and is a Gemini. He lives with Taurus nail technician Zoe Pocock, 36, in Borough, South London.

Fiona says: âThis canine loves accompanying you everywhere and finding out what everyoneâs been up to.

âHe can move like lightning, is extremely bright and adores learning new tricks. His quick mind canât bear to be bored, so donât leave him alone for long if you value your home. The only problem between owner and pet will be Dave does not need to eat as much as Zoe thinks he does.â

Zoe says: âDave sleeps in his own bed and loves cuddles with his mum. He loves biting and stealing peopleâs slippers and shoes.â

Cancer

June 22 - July 22

BORDER terrier Dotty, eight, is a Cancer. Dental hygienist owner Alison Seymour, 47, is an Aquarius and lives in Winchester, Hants.

Fiona says: âDotty, the Cancerian canine, probably tends to be a home-bird.

"She is sensitive, caring â and an excellent addition to the family.

âSoft and gentle on the inside but she can present a rather crusty outer shell to the world. An Aquarius owner will love observing the personality of a Cancerian pet â they will get on well.â

Alison says: âThis sums Dotty up. She is very home-loving and is always a bit unsure when weâre away on holiday.â

Leo

July 23 - August 23

GERMAN shepherd Sky is two and a Leo. She lives in Shenfield, Essex, with mum-of-four Shelley Hutchins, 39, who was born on the cusp of Gemini and Taurus.

Fiona says: âThis canine is loyal with a loving heart. She needs to shine and be treated like the queen she is.

âGrooming procedures will give her the feeling of being adored.

âNever ever scold, her loving heart simply couldnât bear it.

âThings between owner and pet should work well as long as Sky gets lavished with praise.â

Shelley says: âThis is very true, Sky is loving, loyal and trusting but sometimes thinks her way is the right way and doesnât listen.â

Virgo

August 24 - September 22

BRITISH Blue cat Martha, two, is a Virgo. Her owner, Sun beauty writer Lauren Naylor, 31, lives in Wapping, East London, and is a Leo.

Fiona says: âDo make sure Marthaâs bed and bowls are spotless as sheâs a stickler for cleanliness. She can be a bit of a fussy eater too.

âShe thrives on predictability and routine. This is why Virgo dogs really are ideal candidates for training as a helper for the disabled.

âA Virgo pet and Leo owner work well together.â

Lauren says: âThis is very accurate. My dad, David, is disabled and she loves to sleep near him in his wheelchair or keep a watchful eye over him from the stairs.â

Libra

September 23 - October 23

CROSS-BREED Sophie, six, is a Libra. Owner Alexandra Newbury, 30, is a service adviser from Tamworth, Staffs and is a Capricorn.

Fiona says: âThe Libra canine thrives in the company of a significant other and your relationship will be very special.

âSheâs well-mannered, so you can take her anywhere.

âBalance and fairness are important to her, and sheâll expect the same high standards as you when it comes to dining and sleeping in a comfy bed.

âOwner and pet will work well together as long as they spend a lot of time together.â

Alexandra says: âThat is actually freaky as it describes her so well. She expects to sleep on my bed and always wants what Iâm eating for tea. She is well mannered, gentle and calm.

âYou can take her anywhere. Our picture was taken in the pub where she charmed everyone.â

Scorpio

October 24 - November 22

LABRADOR Barney, three, is a Scorpio. He lives with Cancerian office worker Maggie Morgan, 42, in Hamble, Hants.

Fiona says: âThe Scorpio canine tends to be suspicious by nature and terribly nosy which makes him an excellent choice as an airport sniffer dog. Your relationship is likely to be intense, as he may not be happy to share you.

âHe sometimes likes to hide things so you may one day stumble upon hidden treasures that perhaps you thought were lost.

âIn the stars, owner and pet are a good mix because both appreciate closeness.â

Maggie says: âOn every walk, Barney has his nose to the ground, sniffing out who has been out and about on his patch.

âIâm sure heâd be an excellent sniffer dog if heâd been properly trained.

âOnly he knows where he keeps his stash of my socks and gloves.â

Sagittarius

November 23 - December 21

MOGGY Forbes, four, is a Sagittarius. He is owned by Sun Woman acting deputy editor Dulcie Pearce, 30, a Virgo from West London.

Fiona says: âForbes needs freedom to explore and create new experiences.

âHe has a real thirst for adventure and would excel at expeditions.

âIf he does get bored during the day, his sleeping pattern at night may become disturbed.

âOwner and pet may experience a little friction if the adventurous pet makes too much mess for his super-clean Virgo owner.â

Dulcie says: âForbes is a true Sagittarius. His sleep patterns differ on a nightly basis and he will often be awake all night if he is bored in the day.

âHe also likes nothing more than to go on an adventure â usually to stay at my parentsâ house when I go on holiday.â

Capricorn

December 22 - January 20

BLACK and white puss Freddie, six, is a Capricorn and lives with Libran teacher James Burrows, 32, in Colchester, Essex.

Fiona says: âThe Capricorn pet takes life very seriously. He seems wise beyond his years.

âHeâll enjoy showing you just how hard he can work and plod on until he gets it right.

âThis is a good combination of pet and owner as Freddie will feel very settled.â

James says: âFreddie is a very clever cat and loves to show this off.

âHeâs forever catching birds and mice, and loves to bring them to me and show me what he has achieved.â

Aquarius

January 21 - February 18

CROSS-BREED pooch Ralph, two, is an Aquarius â just like writer owner Sally Windsor, 32, of Crawley, Sussex.

Fiona says: âAn Aquarian canine is special and highly intelligent. Heâs a one-off, blessed with an optimistic outlook.

âHeâs very interested in others and always makes them feel welcome.

âHis favourite activity is to run with a pack of canine friends.

âHoroscope-wise owner and pet are a good combination.â

Sally says: âRalph is always trying to make new friends in the park, so heâs a typical Aquarius.

âHe doesnât like sticking to the rules â a bit like me â so the two of us are always getting into trouble together.â

Pisces

February 19 - March 20

JACK Russell Porky, three, is a Pisces. Owner Alison Webster, 49, is a photographer from Kent and is a Gemini.

Fiona says: âAwake or sleeping the Pisces animal just adores being near you.

âWhen she sleeps she may need some encouragement to rise from her slumbers, but once she is out sheâll enjoy herself with you by his side. She offers unconditional love.

âThe star signs of owner and pet work, if the owner takes the pet everywhere.â

Alison says: âPorky loves being around people as sheâs very affectionate and gets jealous if I give others dogs too much attention.

âSheâs very lazy â forever dozing when the rest of the house is up and about.â

pages.subdeck: Trouser 'bout that? ... jeans are on the rise at work
pages.headline: Character is all in your jeans
pages.teaser: AS STUDY shows that denim is more common than suits in the workplace, jeans expert Daniel Miller gives his verdict
pages.articlebody:
THESE new findings do not surprise me at all.

People assume that everybody wants to have strong individuality but we actually found that people strive to become ordinary.

Itâs not OK to say, âWhen I grow up I want to be ordinary,â but actually there are real advantages to it. And jeans are ordinary.

Especially in the workplace, jeans provide a feeling of commonness. They put other people at ease and they make you feel relaxed.

There is a growing trend towards informality in the workplace. The suit is in decline and itâs being replaced with jeans.

Youâre always safe with them and itâs one less thing to worry about.

In the same way that itâs useful at work, we found that itâs useful for students.

When kids go to school they donât want to be fighting for status.

If everybodyâs wearing jeans then everybodyâs happy and on the same level. As part of my study I went all over the world â the Philippines, Turkey, India and Brazil.

One of the first things I did when I got to these countries was stand on a street corner and count the number of people wearing blue jeans out of the first 100.

And in most countries, around half the population wear them. And thatâs kind of amazing.

When you wear jeans you become a citizen of the world.

Everyone wears them â you put babies in jeans and even the elderly â who never used to wear jeans when they were young â wear them now.

Whatâs interesting is that this is clearly not something that has been orchestrated by the fashion industry.

They obviously make some money out of jeans, but would make a lot more money if we bought more diverse fashionable clothes.

My co-author Sophie Woodward and I found that a lot of women will get up in the morning, try on a few outfits, take them off then put on jeans.

So when we study fashion we should probably not turn first to the catwalk but look instead at this anxiety about what to wear.

pages.subdeck: Guilty ... mum Laura Palmer
pages.headline: Mum who left kids home alone to go clubbing hid from cops in her shed
pages.teaser: NEIGHBOURS called cops after finding children running naked in the street next day
pages.articlebody:
A MUM-of-three who left her young children at home to go out clubbing later tried to dodge police by hiding in her garden shed.

A court heard that Laura Palmer put her children, aged three, four, and seven, to bed before going on a night out on June 13 last year.

But the next day, concerned neighbours found the children running naked in the street while covered in faeces.

When police arrived at her house in Hull, East Yorks, they found Palmer drunk and hiding in her shed, still dressed in her clubbing outfit.

Palmer, 26, last week pleaded guilty to three counts of child cruelty and neglect between December 31, 2010, and June 14 last year.

Prosecutor Nick Adlington told Hull Crown Court: âConcerned members of the public called the police because the children were running around near fast-moving traffic.

âThe police took the children back to their home address. It was in a terrible state, covered in excrement and dirt and the children could access dangerous areas of the house, including the kitchen.

âThe defendant was, in due course, found in the garden shed intoxicated, having been out the night before and was still dressed for a night out.

âThe officers described the house as being in a vile state.

âFood debris was all over the living room, the sofa was filthy, there was a broken tumble dryer in the kitchen, there was no bedding on some of the beds and there was rubbish in the bath.

âThere was excrement everywhere and a general air of neglect.â

Palmer claimed she had fallen asleep on a friendâs sofa after a night out, and returned to her home to find the police there.

While she was gone, her children had climbed out of a window and begun running around in the street.

After spotting the police van outside her house, she apparently decided to hide in the shed.

Unemployed Palmer, who has two previous cautions for shoplifting, said she was âdevastatedâ by her actions.

But she claimed that she had not been living at the address, and was expecting to be re-housed the next day.

She told the police: âI have never done it before. Iâm devastated.

"There is no excuse. I just lost the plot and gave up on the house.

âEverything was a total tip. I was expecting to be rehoused."

Recorder Paul Miller told Palmer: âYour children were found in the street, anything could have happened to them but happily they came to no physical or psychological harm.

âIt is clear not all of your problems are your own making. You have suffered a depressive period in the past, but it is no excuse to effectively give up responsibility"

Palmer was given a four-month prison sentence, suspended for 12 months, and a 12-month supervision order.

pages.subdeck: Fan ... Cameron Diaz
pages.headline: Fitness blitz that beats 1hour slog
pages.teaser: DOING as little as four minutes  or one 'HIT'  can be better for you than an hour's slog. See how here
pages.articlebody:
LESS is more when it comes to working out. Doing as little as four minutes  or one "HIT"  can be better for you than an hour's slog.

The four-minute, high-intensity training session can increase your aerobic and anaerobic capacity and speed up the metabolism, helping you burn more fat and make you look 200 per cent leaner than a traditional 60-minute aerobic workout.

Known as the closest thing we have to a fitness miracle, the HIT workout is loved by researchers and fitness pros alike for its fat-torching abilities and simplicity.

Celeb fans include Jessica Biel and Cameron Diaz.

HIT workouts are not easy, but are appealing to time-starved mums, working women and anyone juggling a hectic life.

Sun fitness expert Nicki Waterman says: "My advice is to combine your plan with 30 minutes of aerobic exercise like fast walking, jogging, swimming, cycling or dancing, for example, to get the maximum effect.

"To do a HIT, simply pick an exercise and set a timer for 20 seconds on and ten seconds rest.

"Do the exercise as hard as you possibly can for 20 seconds and then rest for ten, repeating eight to 20 times in total. And remember, you have to work to 100 per cent maximum intensity. By the end of the four minutes you should feel like you've done a full workout and have nothing else to give."

Check out my favourites to get you started for one week.

But please check with your doctor before starting this exercise programme. And always warm up and cool down for at least five minutes before and after each HIT session.

MONDAY: Skipping

CARDIO and coordination all in one. Take a skipping rope and jump as fast as you can, using whichever foot pattern you like.

Options include both feet together, high knees, the "boxer shuffle" with heels in front, alternating feet, and butt-kickers.

Tip: Make sure your rope is long enough before you start  nothing ruins a good HIT workout like getting whipped across your calves.

To check for proper length, stand in the centre of your rope and pull the handles straight up. They should come at least as high as your armpits.

TUESDAY: Jumping Lunges

You already know and love (to hate?) lunges for their butt-blasting ability. Add a jump in between alternating legs to up the difficulty and cardio factor.

Start by stepping your right foot forward into a deep lunge, until your leg is parallel with the ground. Then jump, bringing your back (left) foot forward and landing in a lunge.

Tip: You can step through each lunge if jumping gets too hard.

WEDNESDAY: Box Jumps

Find a weight bench, or a step that hits somewhere between your shins and your knees.

Stand in front of it and jump on top of the bench/step with both feet together.

Jump back to the floor, again with both feet together. Try not to rest when you land and jump right back up again.

If this is too difficult, you can do step-ups onto the box instead.

THURSDAY: Mountain Climbers

Make a triangle with your hands and feet on the floor with your butt up in the air. Bring one leg towards your chest. Keeping hands on the ground, jump to switch your legs.

Tip: Just quickly touch each toe down so you're not resting by putting whole foot down.

FRIDAY: Hindu Squats

These are similar to a traditional squat but instead of stopping when your thighs are parallel to the ground, you continue down, dropping your butt towards your heels until your fingertips brush the ground.

Going through the full range of motion gets your heart rate up faster and engages more muscles.

Tip: Don't be afraid  contrary to popular belief, researchers now say that for healthy people, squatting to the ground won't hurt your knees.

SATURDAY: Bicycle Sprints

Bikes are perfect for engaging your whole lower body and really getting your heart rate up for those 20 seconds.

Tip: It's a little easier to time and to rest on a stationary bike  you can just take your feet off the pedals for ten seconds rather than trying to start and stop/coast on the road.

The HIT diet plan

SUN nutritionist Amanda Ursell says: "If your aim is to lose weight, then you need to combine your workout with a style of eating that provides energy to exercise, yet cuts empty calories that are keeping your body mass index high.

"Timing of your meals and snacks is especially important because your body needs fuel to cope with the HIT workout before you start and, once you have finished, to allow your muscles to recover and be ready for the next hard session.

"Here's how to eat to lose weight but keep your body healthy and able to cope with the HIT plan over the coming week."

Before you train: Whether you train before breakfast, before lunch or at the end of the day before dinner, have something like a handful of raisins, a banana or even a small smoothie an hour to 30 minutes before you start.

During training: Drink "to thirst". This simply means have a drink when you feel the need and stop once you no longer feel thirsty.

After training: Have your meal whether it is breakfast, lunch or dinner within half an hour of finishing. If you can't manage this, have another small snack like some dried fruit or a cereal bar.

YOUR DAILY DIET

Breakfast: This is not the week to skip breakfast, however rushed your daily schedule.

If you are training early, have breakfast once you have finished. If not, make time to have it before you leave the house.

Have a breakfast of porridge made with skimmed or semi-skimmed milk with some dried fruit such as chopped apricots; a wholegrain cereal such as Oatibix or Weetabix or a fruit salad which includes a banana with some zero per cent fat Total Greek yoghurt and a handful of sunflower seeds.

Alternatively, have two poached or boiled eggs with two pieces of toast and a glass of orange or apple juice.

Have a glass of water and your usual cup of tea or coffee using skimmed milk.

Mid-morning: Have a handful of nuts such as almonds, cashews, pistachios or Brazil nuts with an apple, orange or a pear and a glass of water.

Lunch: Build your lunch around an average-sized portion of carbohydrate foods that give you a steady supply of energy. These include pitta breads, tortilla wraps, bread, pasta, noodles, or a baked potato.

To these add some protein-rich food such as tuna, chicken, turkey, lean slices of roast beef, hard-boiled eggs, prawns, cottage or ricotta cheese, pulses such as baked beans, peas or lentils, tofu or Quorn products.

Have some veg with these such as tomato and cucumber in a sandwich, lettuce and spring onions in a wrap or pitta or salad with a baked potato and baked beans. Always have some water with your lunch.

Mid-afternoon: A couple of oat cakes with some cottage or ricotta cheese and berries; a slice of peanut butter on toast; an apple with a small matchbox-size piece of reduced-fat Cheddar or a handful of mixed nuts and raisins.

Dinner: As with lunchtime, dinner needs to be a mix of an average-size serving of carbohydrate-based foods such as new boiled potatoes, pasta, rice or noodles.

To these add some protein-rich foods such as lean red meat  lean mince, a lean pork chop or lean roast lamb; Turkey, chicken or ham; grilled, baked or canned fish; tofu, Quorn mince or "chicken" pieces, pulses such as baked beans.

Also add some vegetables. Broccoli, carrots, cauliflower, green beans, sweetcorn, tomatoes, onions  whichever you enjoy and find easy to prepare.

pages.subdeck: 'Mum says I was born ballsy' ... actress Megan Fox
pages.headline: There is no secret to being a sex symbol. I play the game, that's all
pages.teaser: HOLLYWOOD siren and Transformers star MEGAN FOX on family, fame and films
pages.articlebody:
MEGAN FOX has become one of the world's hottest sex symbols, thanks to hit movies such as Transformers and Jennifer's Body.

She will next be seen  playing herself  in Sacha Baron Cohen's latest film, The Dictator, released on May 11.

Megan, 25, married her long-term boyfriend, 38-year-old actor Brian Austin Green, in 2010 and there are now reports she is pregnant.

Here she speaks to GARTH PEARCE about what her mother taught her.

MY mum Darlene taught me to fight for what I believe. She was strict, but wanted a daughter who could look after herself.

I was not the easiest of girls to bring up. From very young I seemed to know what I wanted to do in life  singing, dancing, acting.

It meant my mum had to drive for miles to take me to various classes. She was always encouraging about self-improvement.

She took me to auditions in Los Angeles, which was on the other side of the country from where we lived in Florida.

I was born in Oak Ridge, a small town in Tennessee, but was brought up mostly in St Petersburg, Florida, after my mother remarried.

When she and Dad were together, they did not have much money. But I was happy as a kid.

It made me realise you don't have to be rich to be happy. My dad used to hunt ducks and my mum would put them in the pot. We lived modestly.

My mum says I was born really ballsy. She's put up with it very well.

I attended a Pentecostal church and then a Christian school. I had to obey strict rules at school and at home. I was grounded a lot.

I got a diploma from a correspondence programme. It was the deal I made with my mum. I had to have a real diploma before she would allow me to drop out of Christian school and move to Los Angeles.

There have been some struggles along the way, which my mum has seen me through. I am also not the easiest of people to be friends with.

I think it is my fault. I work away from home and have learned to be on my own.

I don't socialise much on a film set and don't have to become best friends with the people I work with.

There is a saying in Hollywood that what happens on a film set stays on a film set. But if I'd ever dated a co-star, it would have been downright depressing. Most actors would not appeal to most women, if they actually met them.

I met Brian when I was 18. I was too young to remember his show, Beverly Hills 90210, so I didn't know who he was. But I knew I was instantly in love.

There is no secret to being a sex symbol. I play the game, that's all.

If people want to think of me as wild and crazy, that's up to them. The fact is, I've only had two serious boyfriends in my life  and I married one.

I have the same hang-ups as any other girl. Am I too fat? Too thin? Do I wear the right clothes? You think about it so much, it can hurt how you live.

So am I insecure? God, yes. Show me a woman who says she's totally secure about everything in her life and I will show you a pain in the ass.

There have been some bad moments along the way, during which calls to my mum have meant a lot.

I lived in New York, doing TV comedy Hope & Faith, and it was cold and miserable.

I was either at work or home in a little apartment, on my own. I let whole days slip by, doing nothing.

I am confident in how I project myself but not in terms of how I look. It all came to a head when I was making 2008 film How To Lose Friends And Alienate People in London.

There was one scene in which I danced around in lingerie. I suddenly felt like I couldn't do the scene and asked if I could wear a skirt.

The director, quite rightly, said it would look ridiculous.

But I was not happy. It ended up with the producer serving me a beer before the scene. I was tired from working non-stop on several films, was suffering from jet lag on the trip to England and started to worry about my ability.

That's where Mum comes in. I called her a few times from London and she was able to calm me down and encourage me.

I am still her little girl, whatever way you want to look at it.

pages.subdeck: Cheat is on ... Dee Jones meets her married men on the website Illicit Encounters
pages.headline: I only ever sleep with married men
pages.teaser: SHE doesn't care if her date is rich, handsome or charming  as long as he's not single
pages.articlebody:
SELECTING a slinky dress for her night out, Dee Jones doesn't care if her date is rich, handsome or charming  as long as he's married.

For the past three months, the 33-year-old accountant has been dating attached men  and has no plans to change her ways.

Feeling no guilt, she is unrepentant when it comes to her playgirl lifestyle filled with gifts, lavish meals and no-strings sex.

Here Dee, from Harrow, North London, reveals why she thinks the wives of the married men she dates should be THANKING her rather than feeling angry with her.

Dee says: "There is nothing wrong with what I do. The way I see it, I'm helping the women because the men go home happier. I provide an emotional outlet for men bored by their wives."

In fact, she jokingly refers to herself as "an alternative marriage counsellor".

She continues: "As well as satisfying them, I also give the men advice on their failing personal lives. I love the excitement of doing something I shouldn't.

"And, what's even better is I can hand them back to their wives when I'm done."

A "feisty" woman who has never had a problem getting a date, Dee first went out with a taken man about four years ago.

She recalls: "I enjoyed my time with him and, although it came to an end, it didn't put me off.

"I loved the fact I could be with him when it suited me and I didn't have to be exclusively with him."

Finding herself single again in January after a long-term relationship, Dee decided she was going to hunt down more married men to get some excitement back in her life.

She says: "I just wanted some fun  so I typed 'meet a married man' into an internet search engine."

Within minutes, Dee had created an online profile on the website Illicit Encounters and was receiving loads of requests for dates.

She says: "It is so flattering and exciting. I love knowing that all these men want is to take me out and ravish me."

With no baggage, no strings and no emotional involvement, Dee could have her cake and eat it  at the expense of somebody else.

Shockingly, these types of websites actually facilitate affairs for people who are unhappy in their sex-less relationships but have no intention of leaving their partner.

Career girl Dee is currently seeing three married men "on rotation".

She explains: "Once a fortnight, the men will take me out to posh restaurants or for drinks in swanky bars  I even cook dinner for one of them at my house."

Amazingly, Dee doesn't feel any guilt.

She says: "They are the ones cheating, not me. I have spent all of my adult life in relationships where I have to think about the other person. I deserve time when I only have to think of myself  I am too independent to be in a relationship at the moment."

Naturally, most people who use the site do so in secret. She says: "I find it safer to keep phone contact to a minimum. I don't want anyone's wife to find out.

"I wait for them to contact me  then I know it is safe to reply."

Dee feels this type of dating is particularly good because she gets treated like a princess.

She says: "I get taken to top restaurants and many of the men buy me elaborate gifts  one guy bought me a TV and DVD player. But most importantly, I get showered with affection.

"Ultimately, after a few dates, the evening out will result in sex. If a guy calls and I'm not in the mood, I say so. If, by the end of the date, I want to invite them in, that's my prerogative. I'm totally in control and I love that."

Dee isn't physical with all of them  some men she "helps" just want to talk to her. In fact, she has stayed in steady contact with one man since November but knows she will never meet him.

"We are having an email affair, if there is such a thing," she explains.

"He and I both know that we will never meet due to distance but this suits us both  we flirt and chat online.

"There is obviously something missing in his life that I fill. I am happy to oblige  he is very sweet to me."

Although the majority of her dating experiences have been good, there have been some disastrous ones too.

She says: "It's always a nightmare when they fall in love with you. One guy declared that I belonged to him after only two dates.

"He told me that I wasn't allowed to date or flirt with any other men  hypocritical as he had a wife at home. I ended that quickly."

Dee admits she likes Illicit Encounters because of the upwardly mobile men that the site claims to attract. She says: "On the whole, all of the users are in well-paid jobs.

"The calibre of males I am meeting is certainly what makes me go back for more. They are all well-groomed and sophisticated. Who wouldn't want to be showered with gifts and shown a luxurious lifestyle?"

Asked if she ever gets attached to the men she sleeps with, the answer is a firm no. "I just switch off. I make my intentions clear from the start and once the guidelines are set, there's no going back."

Dee makes extramarital affairs look easy, but they do come with risks.

She says: "All of these men have children and some have been caught out, "It may sound stupid, but I actually think most of the wives involved just turn a blind eye to their husband's infidelity. They have a lifestyle they want to protect.

"Many have the car, the home, the children, the holidays. If they finished the relationship, they would risk losing all that.

"There is nothing more exciting than knowing I'll get to flirt over a candlelit dinner or secretly hold hands in the cinema.

"I know most people think this is all about sex, but it isn't. Despite what people assume, there is an emotional connection and we do think of each other. I wouldn't sleep with just anyone.

"Since I initially logged on, I have only been on dates with around 12 men in total  I am still fussy.

"In a nutshell, I am a bubbly and outgoing woman who loves attention but doesn't want a relationship  this type of lifestyle is tailor-made for me!"

But this isn't a life that Dee will continue with forever.

She says: "I'll stay on the site for a year or so then make a decision about what I want from there. I'm going travelling at Christmas, so it suits me to have another six months of no-strings fun."

Dee describes her last three months as "feeling like a kid in a sweet shop".

She explains: "I'm addicted to the thrill of it. I've found that some of the men are separated but not divorced yet. I'm not interested in them, it's not exciting enough. I go for the ones who are still married."

Asked how she would feel if her future husband cheated on her, she chuckles: "Of course I'd be upset, but there's no way I'll ever conform  that's just the way I am."

pages.subdeck: Looking healthy ... Pixie Lott, left, and Billie Faiers
pages.headline: Go bananas for a tasty new trend
pages.teaser: FRUIT and vegetable prints spill out of the greengrocer's and on to the catwalks to give you a delicious new style
pages.articlebody:
HERE'S a fun way to cram in your five-a-day.

Fruit and veg prints have spilled out of the greengrocer's and on to the catwalks.

Pop princess Pixie Lott, singer Paloma Faith and, er, "socialite" Pixie Geldof have been getting their roughage with designer outfits from Dolce & Gabbana.

But you can snap up the tasty banana print frock, as worn by Towie star Billie Faiers, for a fraction of the price.

pages.subdeck: Quirky ... Jessie J
pages.headline: What your clothes say about YOU
pages.teaser: BEHAVIOUR expert Dr Pam Spurr analyses six celebrities and reveals what their fashion tells us about their personality
pages.articlebody:
MOST of us flash more flesh as the weather warms up but we may not realise what our outfits reveal about our personality.

A new book by US psychologist Dr Jennifer Baumgartner, You Are What You Wear: What Your Clothes Reveal About You, claims to unwrap the secrets behind our choice of outfits.

Here behaviour expert Dr Pam Spurr analyses six celebrities and reveals what their style says about them.

Jessie J



Style: The singer's outlandish styles show she likes to do things her own way.

Style secret: Eccentric dressers may seem extrovert but are often shy deep down. Their clothes may act as armour, diverting attention from them.

Cameron Diaz

Style: The film star's relaxed look indicates a more carefree and grounded personality.

Style secret: When someone feels they are seen chiefly as a sex object, they may downplay their feminine side to show there is more to their character.

Kate, Duchess of Cambridge

Style: As a younger Royal, Kate could push the boat out more with her outfits but plays it safe.

Style secret: Kate probably likes to maintain routine and please others. But some conservative dressers may long to break free.

Christina Hendricks

Style: The vampish Mad Men actress can seem aloof and untouchable.

Style secret: Someone who dresses like this may not feel sexy inside. She might be over-compensating to cover insecurity.

Beyonce

Style: The singer's trademark jewellery reveals a powerful personality who is happy to show she is on top.

Style secret: Lots of flash or expensive gear can mask a deeper insecurity that makes the wearer feel a need to prove themself.

Holly Willoughby

Style: Holly's style is feminine and traditional, but with a twist of sexiness.

Style secret: The girl next door may secretly wish to be more assertive and outgoing. Often more complicated than she appears.

pages.subdeck: Busker to beauty queen ... Miss England contestant Lena Walker
pages.headline: From busker to beauty queen
pages.teaser: ENCOURAGEMENT from passers-by led to teenager entering beauty pageant
pages.articlebody:
A STUNNING busker has turned Miss England hopeful after her fans encouraged her to enter the beauty pageant.

Lena Walker took to the streets of her home city of Leicester with her guitar to raise money for charity.

But the 17-year-old was surprised when scores of people approached her to praise her music  and her good looks.

The pretty student said: "I decided to give busking a go  but never expected the reaction I got.

"Loads of people were coming up to me and commenting on my music, but also my looks."

After entering the Miss England contest, she battled through several rounds to make the national finals.

She added: "I've always been a down-to-earth girl, so had never really considered putting myself in to be judged on my looks.

"But after my family and friends said I should do it, and with the confidence of all the comments from the public, I thought why not."

And after beating off competition from 22 other girls, she will now compete in the Miss England final in Leicester on June 26.

Lena said: "I don't think it has really hit me that I've made it into the last 60 girls left from the whole UK.

"I'm sure it will sink in once I'm on that stage."

And she says she's looking forward to competing in front of her home crowd.

She said: "Hopefully my down-to-earth nature will shine through and win me some support.

"I'll have plenty of family and friends there, what with it being held in my home town.

"It could be a struggle fitting them all in!"

If things don't work out, Lena may still have a career in music  as she raised a whopping £35 an hour while busking

But the big-hearted student donated the cash she raised to charities.

She added: "The public have been very generous whenever I have put myself on a limb and taken to the streets to play my music.

"I play a lot of my own stuff that I write, but also play a few crowd-pleasers like David Guetta, Jessie J and Foster The People.

"On a good day I've made £35 an hour and would stay for a couple of hours at least.

"It isn't all glamour though. I'd often get back from a session busking and your fingers would be numb thanks to the cold."

pages.subdeck: 'My photo journey reminds me how hard I worked' ... Nicola Williams
pages.headline: 11st weightloss picture diary
pages.teaser: TEACHER shares snaps she took every month until she reached her goal...a size 12
pages.articlebody:
WHEN primary school teacher Nicola Williams decided to lose weight, she looked to herself for inspiration.

She decided to take a self-portrait every month to clearly see her progress and motivate her to continue.

Her inspiring photo casebook charts her epic FOUR-YEAR weight loss  from 24 stone and a size 32 to the 13 stone size 12 she is today.

Her incredible photo diary helped her jack in the junk food and bin the bad habits in pursuit of a healthier, happier life.

Now, looking back through the pictures proves incredibly emotional for Nicola, 39.

She says: "When I show people they stare open-mouthed as I flick through the album and shrink before their eyes.

I can't believe how big I was and how much I've transformed. It's incredible and I love the new improved me.

"My photo journey reminds me of how hard I worked to get where I am today and I hope it inspires other women to begin their own journey."

At the age of 24, Nicola was 16 stone and by the time she was 34 she weighed 24st.

She recalls: "I worried if I was going to fit through a small gap or get stuck on a small chair. So I'd try to avoid putting myself in potentially embarrassing situations.

"For breakfast, I'd have four slices of toast. For lunch I'd make a sandwich with four slices of white bread with double the filling.

"Dinners were always whatever was quick. Pasta bakes, pizzas and takeaways were my regular meals of choice.

"My biggest weakness though, were crisps. I'd never go a day without eating at least three bags.

"Working as a primary school teacher, the staff room is always full of cakes and chocolates to snack on during break times."

Nicola, of Llanelli, Wales, was eating around 4,900 calories a day, 2,900 above the recommended intake. And it affected her confidence.

She says: "Trying to run around with the kids during PE lessons and teaching them about healthy lifestyles was always difficult as I felt like a hypocrite."

She also struggled to find clothes to flatter her huge frame. She continues: "I had to settle for T-shirts that managed to cover my enormous body and trousers that didn't dig in to my sides.

"The only things that looked good were shoes. I loved being able to walk into High Street shops and pick out a pair of pretty high heels, slip them on my feet and feel sexy.

"So I went crazy for them. Platforms, stilettos, boots, wedges  you name them, I had a pair. In every colour and for every occasion I had shoes that made me feel great.

"Worth more than £3,500, I had just over 100 pairs in my collection before my life changed."

Then, in December 2007, Nicola joined a weekly slimming class  purely to keep a friend company.

She says: "I swapped white bread for brown, reduced my portion sizes and snacked on fruit and veg. I found it surprisingly refreshing to come out of my normal convenience eating routine and try something new."

Within a month, Nicola had shed 10lb. Yet she struggled to see a difference in her appearance.

"So my friend suggested taking a picture to show me how well I'd done. It was the motivation I needed to carry on," she says.

"Comparing myself month by month stunned me. My face was thinner and I could notice the difference in my waistline and arms.

"I began looking forward to each month when the time came to take a picture and compare myself to the previous one."

Nicola also joined women-only gym Curves and began working out twice a week.

She says: "After the first year I'd lost five stone  down from 24st to 19st.

"My meals changed completely to consist of a piece of toast for breakfast, a sandwich with two pieces of brown bread for lunch, fruit for a snack and meat with vegetables for dinner.

"Looking at myself filled me with pride and the compliments I was receiving from friends and family were incredible.

"I was determined this wasn't going to just be a fad diet phase  this was a new lifestyle for me."

In the next three years she lost a further six stone, dropping to 13st 2lb.

Nicola says: "Every woman wants to look their best in a photo.

"If I was ever tempted to have a take-away binge at the end of the month, I'd think about having my picture taken and it would put me off."

And for shoe-mad Nicola there was only one way to mark her sensational new figure.

"In January this year I splashed out on a beautiful pair of £380 cream Jimmy Choo shoes to celebrate."

pages.subdeck: Incredible figure ... mum-of-fourteen Nadya Suleman
pages.headline: 'Octomom' poses for topless snaps
pages.teaser: MUM-OF-FOURTEEN poses for topless snaps three years after having her octuplets
pages.articlebody:
MUM-of-fourteen Nadya Suleman shows off her incredible post-babies body in these revealing snaps.

Nadya, dubbed "Octomom" after giving birth to octuplets in 2009, happily posed topless for a magazine shoot.

And while she boasts of attracting plenty of admirers with her flat stomach and 34DD boobs, she claims she has been celibate for 13 years  as her children were all conceived through a sperm donor.

She explained: "I get way too much male attention, but I won't date until the octuplets are 18  I live for them now.

"I know a lot of women like male attention, but I'll go out with no make-up on and wear tracksuits, a wig and even a fake pregnancy stomach to put them off."

She added: "I wouldn't rule out a relationship in the future. But now, when men look at me, I look away and they know not to approach me.

"I know I'm beautiful  I don't need a man to tell me that."

Nadya, who lives in California, US, already had six kids  Elijah, now 10, Amerah, nine, Joshua, eight, Aiden, six, and twins Caleb and Calyssa, five, when she claims she decided to have more embryos implanted from the same sperm donor.

And her brood was soon joined by six boys and two girls  Noah, Jonah, Jeremiah, Isiah, Josiah, McCai, Maliah and Nariah, who turned three in January this year.

But amazingly, the 36-year-old says it was no effort at all to get her figure back following her last pregnancy.

She explained: "I just pinged back into shape like a rubber band after the kids  I don't know how I did it.

"I eat like a horse, don't count calories and have never owned a set of scales.

"I gained an entire human when I was pregnant with the octuplets  going from 10st to over 19st  but, two months later, I was a size eight again. Now, I never weigh myself."

  • The full feature appears in this month's Closer magazine, on sale now.

image.caption: Incredible figure ... mum-of-fourteen Nadya Suleman

pages.subdeck: Kate expectations ... have other stars aged as well as Winslet?
pages.headline: Stars looking better with age
pages.teaser: AS Kate looks more beautiful on Titanic 3D red carpet than the original film's premiere other stars who've aged well
pages.articlebody:
KATE WINSLET swept into the Titanic 3D premiere this week looking even MORE beautiful than when the original film came out in 1997.

But the actress, 36, is not the only beauty who manages to look hotter now than when she first found fame.

Here ANTONELLA LAZZERI profiles other women who have only got better over the past 15 years, with pictures of then and now  as well as a couple who haven't aged quite so well.

Carol Vorderman, 51

Tended to be a bit frumpy and covered up in early days but now proud to show curves. She denies having plastic surgery saying: "It's been reported that I've had so much done but if it was all true I'd look a lot better than I do now."

Amanda Holden, 41

Doris Day goody-two-shoes look is long gone. Now all about sexiness  and bit of Botox.

Denise Van Outen, 37

Party girl did always look great, but says she feels more confident in her body now  and it shows.

Jennifer Aniston, 43

Famous for her hairstyles on Friends, her approach to beauty over the years radiates class.

Kate Beckinsale, 38

Keeps getting more dazzling and is still a regular in People magazine's list of the world's sexiest women.

Kelly Brook, 32

Turned to modelling after being sacked from TV's The Big Breakfast in 1999  and now a huge success. Kelly credits the fact she's been a dancer since a young child and still dances now as keeping her body in trim.

Dannii Minogue, 40

Took off in style stakes with The X Factor in 2007 and her many hair styles. Danni has admitted having plastic surgery to make her 'look nice'. She's believed to have had a nose job, boob job and regular botox.

Cameron Diaz, 39

As thin as she was as a teen model. Credits pilates, aerobics and refusal to eat processed food. Despite having no wrinkles and an excessively smooth forehead she swears she's not had plastic surgery. She did have her nose fixed in 2006 after breaking it in an accident.

Gwyneth Paltrow, 39

Has kept her youthful looks and thanks her workouts, yoga, healthy diet and good marriage. Gwyneth, who runs a blog about healthy living, doesn't appear to have turned to the plastic surgeon.

And two who aren't...

Kerry Katona, 31

Atomic Kitten found fame in 1999  but since then her weight has yo-yoed. As a mum of four, Kerry admits she has seen her weight go from a size 6-8 to a size 14 through the years.

Mariah Carey, 42

Has struggled with her weight since winning over the world with her sexy Latin American looks. After the birth of her twins in 2011, she shed 70lbs but she has since regained much of the weight.

image.caption: Kate expectations ... have other stars aged as well as Winslet?

pages.subdeck: Split ... Dannii Minogue and Kris Smith
pages.headline: Dannii Minogue and Kris Smith split
pages.teaser: FORMER X Factor judge Dannii Minogue and Kris Smith have separated
pages.byline: By ANGHARAD LLEWELLYN and ANNE RICHARDSON
pages.articlebody:
FORMER X Factor judge Dannii Minogue and Kris Smith have split, it has emerged.

The couple separated two weeks ago and Kris, 33, has moved out of their home.

The couple, who have a 21-month-old son Ethan, starting dating in 2008 after meeting in Ibiza.

Dannii, 40, was a judge on the X Factor but quit to return to Australia.

She mentored Matt Cardle who won the show in 2010 and scored a number one hit with When We Collide.

Dannii and Kris used to send lots of messages on Twitter but she last mentioned him on March 8 while on a photoshoot in South Africa, writing: "Sending big love from Capetown #wishingmyboyswerehere."

In February Kris changed his Twitter profile to read: "It's nice to be important, but it's more important to be nice ... not really sure what my job is any more ... but I do know I love my boy more than life."

The couple were at the centre of split rumours last year.

Dannii hinted at problems in a tweet, saying: âNever chase love. If it isnât given freely, itâs not worth having.â Kris replied: âYou donât know what youâve lost til itâs gone.â

Dannii joined the X Factor in 2007 and, besides Matt, also mentored winner Leon Jackson.

She rose to fame after a role in Australian soap opera Home And Away where she played Emma Jackson.

She then went on to have a successful pop career with hits including All I Wanna Do and Who Do You Love Now?

Her latest venture is fashion label Project D, which she runs with her pal Tabitha Sommerset Webb.

Last year she received an honorary doctorate degree from Southampton Solent University in Media and Arts.

Her sister, pop princess Kylie Minogue, is currently dating Andres Valencoso Segura.

Elle teamed the stripy red halter-neck dress with some super-high gladiator-style sandal boots, a furry black handbag and oversized shades.

pages.headline: 'Simon can't stop raving about Jessie J'
pages.teaser: COWELL'S pal Sinitta says the BGT judge is a huge fan of his Voice rival Jessie J
pages.articlebody:
SIMON Cowell can't stop talking about his Saturday night telly rival Jessie J, his former flame Sinitta has revealed.

Sinitta said the Britainâs Got Talent supremo is obsessed with singer Jessie, a coach on The Voice, and has been "raving about her".

And she even thinks the music mogul should sign up the 24-year-old Londoner for a judging role on the American X Factor panel.

BBC1's The Voice and ITV1's Britainâs Got Talent are currently going head to head on Saturday nights.

And Sinitta hasn't been helping her pal win the battle for viewing figures.

She has admitted she is in trouble with Simon for watching the competition — after being caught tweeting about The Voice.

She said: âSimonâs not amused. Not amused.

âBut the way he keeps raving about Jessie J, I suspect he's doing the same thing.

âI love Jessie J and Danny (O'Donoghue) and of course Tom Jones, but Jessie J is just adorable.

âIf I was Simon I would replace both X Factor US judges with Jessie J.â

Simon has said that despite the raven-haired singer taking a role on the rival show, he would still sign her up for the X Factor "in an instant".

But Jessie replied to his offer with a polite "thanks but no thanks", insisting she is happy at The Voice and is "not going anywhere".

pages.articlebody:
RICKY Gervais has released the first trailers for his brand new sitcom Derek.

The Office creator stars with long-term friend and Idiot Abroad collaborator Karl Pilkington in the new show.

Showing on April 12th, the pilot episode follows Derek Noakes who works in a retirement home alongside Karlâs character Dougie.

After the controversy of âMong-gateâ, it could be seen as a risky move for Ricky, as Derek is a simple soul with an unfortunate underbite and dodgy haircut, who views the world through innocent eyes.

But with laughs, tears, cringeworthy moments and plenty of heart â but without the cynicism or self-delusion of David Brent or Andy Millman â it is a welcome return to form for the Extras actor.

pages.subdeck: Tears for her father ... Katherine Jenkins sobs as the judges praise her near-perfect waltz
pages.headline: Jenkins sobs on Dancing With The Stars
pages.teaser: OPERA singer Katherine Jenkins weeps as she performs emotional waltz for her late father
pages.articlebody:
KATHERINE Jenkins broke down in tears on live television as she danced an emotional routine in tribute to her late father.

The opera singer scored a near-perfect 29 out of 30 on last nightâs Dancing With The Stars, as she performed a waltz to Josh Grobanâs To Where You Are.

Dancing with her professional partner Mark Ballas, the routine was a tribute to Katherineâs dad Selwyn, who died in 1996. She had chosen to dance the routine on the US version of Strictly Come Dancing, during the Most Important Year Of Your Life theme week.

The Welsh warbler sobbed as the judges praised her impressive and emotional performance. And afterwards her mum Susan, who was in the audience, gave her a big hug.

Katherine — who used to be engaged to Strictly contestant Gethin Jones — is going down a storm on the US show, having topped the leaderboard for three weeks running.

And later that night the 31-year-old celebrated yet another triumphant performance by donning a slinky navy backless catsuit and heading to West Hollywood bar Mixology 101 for the DWTS after-party.
