pages.articlebody:
FLAMBOYANT funnyman Kenny Everett is the subject of a new BBC4 biopic, The Best Possible Taste.

The programme follows the unconventional love story between Kenny (Oliver Lansley) and his wife Lee Middleton, played by Katherine Kelly.

The Corrie favourite hasnât been seen on telly since she quit the cobbles earlier this year.

Featuring some of Everettâs most famous characters including Sid Snot and Cupid Stunt, the 90-minute film will show how the irreverent funnyman became one of Britainâs best-loved, most rebellious and innovative broadcasters.

Kenny, who died in April 1995 at the age of 50 from an Aids-related illness, rose to fame as a radio DJ, and the host of The Kenny Everett Television Show.

  • The Best Possible Taste will be aired later this year.

pages.subdeck: Sex And The City ... original programme had racy storylines
pages.headline: Teenage Carrie on
pages.teaser: NEW Sex And The City spin-off pilot has the kind of storylines you’d expect in Skins episode
pages.articlebody:
JUST when every bloke regained control of the TV remote, another series of Sex And The City rears its ugly head.

A spin-off show is being made which covers main character Carrie Bradshaw as a teenager.

And unsurprisingly for the new series, some of the scenes for the pilot show are pretty shocking.

There are drug references, teen sex scenes and underage boozing. In one scene a friend of Carrieâs loses her virginity and another sees her younger sister caught with marijuana.

A source said: âThe CW network made sure the TV show reflects the original programme, which had quite a few racy storylines.

âBecause itâs teenagers, theyâve had to be very careful â think Skins meets SATC.â

But not set in Bristol, unfortunately.

AnnaSophia Robb to Carrie on the Sex And The City legacy

The troubled star, who was fired from hit sitcom Two And A Half Men last year, will make his TV comeback in comedy Anger Management alongside his famous actor dad Martin.

The show, which is based on the 2003 Jack Nicholson film of the same name, will air this summer.

Charlie, who plays an ex-baseball star undergoing therapy, told Access Hollywood: âWeâre going to find out this guy does have major issues with his pop and when that character does finally show up it will be my dad.â

Jenny, 34, refuses to rejoin the band if founder member Kerry, 31, is going to be in it too.

She has said she will come back as a trio with Natasha Hamilton and Liz McClarnon â but nothing else.

Now manager Martin OâShea is said to be frantically trying to compromise.

pages.subdeck: Reunited ... Davina McCall returns for second series of Long Lost Family
pages.headline: Davina McCall’s big reunion
pages.teaser: TV PRESENTER is turning detective again – to reunite loved ones for a second series of Long Lost Family
pages.articlebody:
DAVINA McCall is turning detective again â to reunite loved ones for a second series of Long Lost Family.

Only the hardest of hearts wouldnât be moved by the show, which sees Davina and Nicky Campbell help relatives find missing members of their clan.

The seven-parter will look at how they became estranged and follow the process of tracing the family through to an emotional reunion.

Davina said: âIf you thought series one was emotional, youâve not seen anything yet.

âThe stories weâve unearthed this time round will tug at your heart-strings like never before. Get ready to start stockpiling those tissues!â

The searches often take unpredictable turns and will see Nicky â who was adopted as a baby â journey to South Africa, Texas, France and Spain to bring people back together again.

The presenters help one woman who is searching for the brother she hasnât seen since he was thrown out of the family home more than 40 years ago.

Meanwhile, a young woman wants to trace the dad she last saw at the age of five.

  • Long Lost Family is back on ITV1 from Thursday next week.

pages.subdeck: YOU CANNOT BE SERIOUS ... Jose Mourinho reacts to speculation
pages.headline: Mourinho slams City rumours
pages.teaser: JOSE MOURINHO has hit out at stories linking Real Madrid striker Gonzalo Higuain with Manchester City
pages.articlebody:
JOSE MOURINHO has hit out at stories linking Real Madrid striker Gonzalo Higuain with Manchester City.

The Argentine ace was reported to be included in a cash-plus-player bid by Real for City's Sergio Aguero.

But Mourinho said: "If you want me to comment on false front covers then forget it."

The Special One himself has been rumoured to be in talks with City over replacing Roberto Mancini, although he denies that is the case.

And Mourinho has grown frustrated by the constant speculation about him and his players.

He added: "You (the press) want to destabilise the squad.

"Last week I had signed for City, Iker Casillas was going to Schalke, Higuain to Malaga..."

Meanwhile, Real's director of institutional relations Emilio Butragueno insisted Higuain was going nowhere.

Butragueno said: "Rumours seem to be inevitable but we are delighted with Higuain.

"He's scored 24 goals in 20 league games."He is a world-class striker and we intend for him to stay here many years.

"He arrived here very young and we regard him as a club player.

"He has always behaved impeccably, whether he plays or not."

image.caption: YOU CANNOT BE SERIOUS ... Jose Mourinho reacts to speculation

pages.subdeck: LIONHEART ... Alex Oxlade-Chamberlain has one eye on Poland and Ukraine
pages.headline: I’ll be England’s Ox in the box
pages.teaser: ARSENAL winger wants to gatecrash Three Lions squad for Euro 2012 this summer
pages.articlebody:
ALEX OXLADE-CHAMBERLAIN wants to gatecrash Englandâs squad for Euro 2012.

And the Arsenal speedster is boldly predicting victory for the Three Lions this summer.

The 18-year-old has earned rave reviews for his performances this year in both the Premier League and Champions League.

And while no full time England manager is in place, Oxlade-Chamberlain hopes whoever replaces Fabio Capello permanently has been watching him.

He said: âIt would be very nice but I donât get too far ahead of myself or get carried away.

âThere are a lot of good teams like Spain and Holland, but you have to say England have what it takes to get to the final and even win it.

âWe have a lot of really good players in this country and a lot of experienced players.â

Oxlade-Chamberlain is one of several Arsenal youngsters who have put their hands up for Euro 2012, with Jack Wilshere and Theo Walcott also in the frame.

He said: âThe fact that they are pushing on already and are in the England squad, while playing week in week out in the Premier League, can only be good.

âThere are a lot of English players coming through, such as the likes of Danny Welbeck and Kyle Walker, while at Arsenal we have the likes of Jack Wilshere and Theo.

âAs long as everyone keeps progressing as they are at the moment, it will be good for Englandâs future.

âWe have a lot of English talent here at Arsenal and we will all be working hard to get into the national team.

âThe longer you play with people, the better you get to know them.

âYou bond, and being around the same players means that you bounce off each other. It will be good for the future.

âFor their age, they are all really mature and fearless.

âYou forget how young Jack is â he is such a confident lad â but at the same time they are all humble as well.

âWhen it comes to football, they are really focused and just get on with the job.

âThey are technically very good and have the right mindsets to become world-class players.â

Oxlade-Chamberlain knows he must continue performing for Arsenal if he is to stand any chance of booking a place on the plane to Poland and Ukraine.

The Gunners are currently in a four-way battle to secure Champions League football next season, with arch-rivals Tottenham level on points, and Chelsea and Newcastle a further five behind.

Oxlade-Chamberlain added: âMy main focus is to see the end of the season out with Arsenal and help us do as well as we can.

âWe have a long way to go to get a Champions League spot and hopefully top three as well.

âIt would be very nice, but one step at a time is the way to go.â

image.caption: LIONHEART ... Alex Oxlade-Chamberlain has one eye on Poland and Ukraine

pages.subdeck: AT A LOSS ... Dalglish after Reina's red card
pages.headline: Time the Yanks backed Kenny
pages.teaser: IAN WRIGHT says Liverpool need some positive words to come from across the pond
pages.articlebody:
WHEN John W Henry took over at Liverpool, he knew he was getting a club with a massive history and a massive trophy cabinet.

But right now the place has become a massive, open sore â one which everyone outside Anfield is picking at with almost rampant relish.

So whatâs the best way to close that wound? Well a few words from across the pond â and the Redsâ American owners â certainly would not go amiss.

After Sundayâs shocker away to Newcastle, more the events surrounding the defeat than the loss itself, the forums and phone-ins have once again been flooded by those questioning whether Kenny Dalglish is up to the job.

Yet all weâve had from America, and Fenway Sports Group, has been the sound of silence. And going into such a crucial couple of weeks, that is doing nobody any good at all.

Should Dalglish get the push? Should they cut their losses on the signings who have flopped? Or should they stick with them in the belief they will come good in the end?

All questions being raised by those keen to take a pot-shot at King Kenny and the club.

In my view, the Americans should stick with Dalglish at least until Christmas â and only then consider a change of manager if things arenât going well.

I know the owners didnât buy the club with the aim of winning the Carling Cup and hopefully the FA Cup. They signed up for title challenges and Champions League charges and, right now, they are a million miles off that.

But the fact is they could still end this season with two trophies and they would have been happy with that at the start of it.

Yet the one thing you need if youâre going to be successful is unity.

And the Americans could help a lot in that direction with just a few public words of backing.

Just a couple of sentences is all it would take. Something along the lines of âKennyâs the manager we want, weâve got faith in what heâs doing and thereâs still a lot to play forâ.

If they want to go back to being silent after that, fair enough.

But right now they do need to say something, if only to allow everyone to focus on what REALLY matters â matches and results.

And letâs be honest, everyone at Liverpool has to be pulling in the right direction if they are to avoid the season disappearing down the plughole.

Theyâll be facing a rampant Everton side in the FA Cup semi-final on Saturday week, a world away from the one which lost the derby at Anfield recently.

So what better way to give a message of unity than hearing one from the very top? At least then there will be no distractions from the job in hand.

I must admit any other manager than Dalglish would have been on the thinnest of ice there if league results had gone as they have of late.

But they wanted Roy Hodgson out, they wanted Dalglish in and thatâs what they got â and owners, fans, the lot have to support him and the club more than ever at the moment.

And I include the players in that, because there are a few who owe him a heck of a lot. Not least of them Andy Carroll.

His reaction at being taken off at Newcastle, in cursing in full view of everyone, could well have been out of disappointment at his own performance rather than abuse at Dalglish.

But he should have been more professional about things and after the faith Kenny has shown in him, he certainly needs to repay a little.

I couldnât believe the way he went sprawling to try to win a penalty when heâd have had a tap-in by staying on his feet. He owes his manager a goal, not a dive, and that was his chance.

Itâs pretty obvious that, possibly Luis Suarez and Jose Enrique apart, the new signings havenât really delivered. But I wouldnât give up on them yet.

I still believe Stewart Downing can be a top, top player, while Jordan Henderson is only a young lad at 21.

Just like Robin van Persie at Arsenal, so much at Liverpool revolves around Steven Gerrard.

He has been injured for a lot of the season but, if he stays fit, Liverpool can match anyone so a lot will depend on that.

Yet if anyone can turn things around, itâs Kenny along with first-team coach Steve Clarke.

Maybe itâs just a case of things not quite clicking but I donât believe that means it never will.

If it doesnât get any better early next season then, fair enough, think about change.

But right now whatâs needed more than anything is unity and support â and that has to start with a few words from America.

Silence certainly isnât golden in this instance.

article.caption: Dalglish: We must stick together
Why has it all gone wrong?
Kenny caught in pitch battle
It’s a f****** joke, f*** off
Kenny to face USA grilling
Doni finale

image.caption: AT A LOSS ... Dalglish after Reina's red card
Ian Wright says it is time Liverpool's owners backed Kenny Dalglish

pages.subdeck: TON IT AGAIN ... Mahela Jayawardene proves England's nemisis
pages.headline: Jayawardene ton on see-saw day one
pages.teaser: SRI LANKAN skipper struck 105 but tourists battle hard on tough day one in Colombo
pages.articlebody:
MAHELA JAYAWARDENE stroked his second century this series as England battled hard on day one of the Second Test in Colombo.

The Sri Lankan skipper — whose 180 in Galle set up the 75-run win — registered an attractive 105 to help his side reach 238-6 at stumps.

It was also the second time in a row Jayawardene has made triple-figures after arriving at the crease to face a hat-trick ball.

James Anderson was the man to strike early, reducing the hosts to 30-3 in the morning session — including the prized scalp of Kumar Sangakkara first ball yet again.

But Jayawardene's 216-ball knock — a masterclass in patience and technique — ensured the home side recovered.

Graeme Swann removed the right-hander shortly after his 31st Test ton, before Steven Finn accounted for wicketkeeper Prasanna Jayawardene with the second new ball.

Some will argue Andrew Strauss and Co shaded the day. But we have been here before — the tail must still be removed and a stronger batting performance than previously witnessed this winter is required.

Failure to win here would see a series defeat and the loss of their World No1 Test status.

With Stuart Broad injured, England opted to drop Monty Panesar and bolster their seam attack with Finn and Tim Bresnan.

But it was the familiar figure of Anderson who drew first blood.

Tillakaratne Dilshan nicking to Matt Prior after a wild 14-run cameo and Sangakkara bagging a second golden duck of the series with Strauss juggling a catch at first slip.

Jayawardene saw off the hat-trick ball, but Anderson had not finished his morningâs work, seeing off Lahiru Thirimanne after he unwisely padded up to straight one.

That brought Thilan Samaraweera to the crease and he soon set about rebuilding with his captain.

He and Jayawardene took their side to 82-3 at lunch, combining for a stand of 124 in total.

Finn thought he had Samaraweera caught at short-leg for 36 only for the umpires — both on the field and on review — to disagree.

England were unimpressed by the verdict, with team director Andy Flower seen remonstrating with officials.

Bresnan finally broke the stand after 43 wicketless overs, going full and straight just before tea to trap Samaraweera lbw for 54.

Jayawardene had a moment of fortune on 79, edging Anderson just wide of Straussâ left hand at slip and picking up four runs in the process.

He was held up by a drinks break one short of his landmark, before nudging Samit Patel into the on-side to bring up his century.

Angelo Mathews had settled at the other end too, doing his part to rotate the strike in a stand of 62.

England were struggling until Swann, bowling round the wicket, finally found a way past Jayawardeneâs bat and won an lbw verdict from Asad Rauf.

Strauss celebrated by unwrapping the new ball and Finn obliged by snaring Englandâs sixth wicket, Prasanna Jayawardene caught behind for seven.

Mathews had eked an important 41 not out by the close, with Suraj Randiv with him overnight.

image.caption: TON IT AGAIN ... Mahela Jayawardene proves England's nemisis
GOT 'IM ... Graeme Swann celebrates the key wicket of Jayawardene
EARLY STRIKES ... James Anderson starred with the new ball

pages.subdeck: YOUNG LOVE ... Valencia plants a smacker on pal Ash
pages.headline: Ant’s the king of the wingers
pages.teaser: ASHLEY YOUNG has hailed Antonio Valencia as the king of the wingers
pages.articlebody:
ASHLEY YOUNG has hailed Antonio Valencia as the king of the wingers.

Flying Valenciaâs thrilling opener got the ball rolling on Manchester Unitedâs 2-0 over Blackburn last night.

And fellow wideman Young, who scored the second, said: âAntonio was brilliant and he got his rewards with a goal.â

Valencia crashed home from just inside the box after catching keeper Paul Robinson napping.

Some pundits suggested it was a shot â but Young insisted: âAs a fellow winger I will give him it as a shot.

United full-back Rafael added: âMaybe the keeper wasnât expecting a shot from that distance. That is why it went in.

âHe just plays his natural game and gets better and better all the time.â

article.caption: Vallelujah
Top Gea or Dodgy Gea?

pages.subdeck: AIMING HIGH ... Emmanuel Adebayor
pages.headline: Adebayor wants to end season with a bang
pages.teaser: EMMANUEL ADEBAYOR admits he’ll only be satisfied if Spurs can seal a Champions League place and win the FA Cup
pages.articlebody:
EMMANUEL ADEBAYOR admits heâll only be satisfied if Spurs can seal a Champions League place and win the FA Cup.

The on-loan striker bagged two late goals in Tottenhamâs crucial Premier League win over Swansea on Sunday.

And that win moved them level on points with third-placed North London rivals Arsenal and back on track for a top-four finish.

Adebayor says one of the reasons he moved to Tottenham was to help his adopted club land a place in Europeâs elite competition once again.

And with an FA Cup semi-final against Chelsea next weekend, the Togolese is also targeting his first ever cup winnersâ medal in what might be his only season at the Lane.

Adebayor said: âFor me my target before coming to join Tottenham was to get in to the top four and we are in a good position to do that now.

âWe are in the FA Cup semi-final as well. We just have to give it a go, try to give everything and finish in the top four, and why not win the FA Cup as well?

âWhen Swansea pulled it back to 1-1 it was quite difficult, but in the head we have a good squad, we have belief.

âWe knew in our heads that we could change it around. We showed character and personality by winning right at the end.

âNow we have closed the gap on Arsenal and have maintained a gap over Chelsea and Newcastle.

âIt was very important for everyone, for the players and the fans, and hopefully now we will go on a good run until the end of the season.â

image.caption: AIMING HIGH ... Emmanuel Adebayor

pages.subdeck: ACE ... Martin Kaymer during his practice round at Augusta
pages.headline: Smart Mart holes amazing trick shot
pages.teaser: Former World No1 Martin Kaymer warmed up for this week's Masters with an unbelievable hole-in-one
pages.articlebody:
SOMETIMES seeing really is believing.

Former World No1 Martin Kaymer warmed up for this week's Masters with an unbelievable hole-in-one at the par-three 16th at Augusta.

The German tried his luck with a trick shot during a practice round ahead of the year's first major which begins on Thursday.

And he wowed the crowds by skipping the ball across the pond near the 16th green and watched as it trickled down the hill and into the pin.

Kaymer however isn't the only man to sink this stunning shot. Former Masters winner Vijay Singh also aced the 16th with a similar shot in 2009.

Watch our amazing video of Kaymer's effort below.

article.caption: No putts – I am the best around
Justin targets jinx

pages.subdeck: KEEPING THEM IN IT ... David de Gea was United star
pages.headline: Top Gea or Dodgy Gea?
pages.teaser: SUNSPORT puts David de Gea under the microscope following United’s 2-0 win
pages.articlebody:
DAVID DE GEA had a stinker against Blackburn in December but Manchester United boss Alex Ferguson insists he has matured into a class keeper.

Is the 21-year-old now in Top Gea or is he still Dodgy Gea?

SHOT STOPPING â TOP

THREE decent saves in the first half with the best one coming when he tipped over Marcus Olssonâs 20-yarder.

A full-stretch save to deny Junior Hoilett and a tip over from Grant Hanley were a bit âHollywoodâ but needed stopping.

DISTRIBUTION â TOP

ONE or two rash clearances but this is one area which has improved as his confidence has grown.

Tried to get rid of the ball early where possible as United were given so much time to build their attacks by Rovers.

CROSSES â DODGY

YOU know you are going to be tested at Blackburn with Morten Gamst Pedersenâs long throws and set-pieces.

He looked shaky on occasion â notably from one throw when he redeemed himself by tipping over Olssonâs shot.

TEMPERAMENT â TOP

LOOKED a bag of nerves when he first arrived but is much more self-assured now.

With Anders Lindegaard injured, De Gea is established as the United first choice and that has done him the power of good.

VERDICT â TOP

IF the shock defeat to Rovers at Old Trafford on New Yearâs Eve was his low point so far, then this was one of his best days for United.

The champions could easily have been beaten but for their young keeper.

article.caption: Blackburn 0 Manchester United 2
Vallelujah

image.caption: KEEPING THEM IN IT ... David de Gea was United star

pages.subdeck: ALL SMILES ... Barcelona's Lionel Messi in training yesterday
pages.headline: Lion must roar against Italians
pages.teaser: LIONEL MESSI must end an open-play goal-drought against Italian clubs to lead Barcelona past Milan
pages.articlebody:
LIONEL MESSI must end an open-play goal drought against Italian clubs to lead Barcelona past Milan and into a possible Champions League semi-final against Chelsea.

Maestro playmaker Xavi is set to start after training this morning despite a foot niggle.

Xavi should be in the squad â giving Messi and Barca a massive boost.

The worldâs best player has only scored a penalty in six matches against Italian clubs â thatâs nine hours of football.

Though that goal was against Milan when it came from the spot in the group stage this season, in Barca's 3-2 win at Milan.

Messi will certainly need to work his magic tonight with the tie in the balance after the goalless draw at the San Siro last week.

Since Valentineâs Day, Messi has scored in EVERY Barca match bar one â last weekâs tussle in Milan.

Barcelonaâs superstar has 19 goals in the last 10 matches â the only time he, and Barca, failed to score was last week.

Boss Pep Guardiola warned the Italian media they were tempting fate by pointing out the niggling stat.

Guardiola made us all laugh in a packed Nou Camp press room as he said: âDonât provoke Leo, you know how he is. Weâll see who is right tomorrow night.â

Thatâs all the Pep talk Messi needed, really.

Last time a stat like that cropped up was in 2009 before the Rome final between Barca and Manchester United.

Someone pointed out Messi had not scored in 10 matches against English opposition.

Weeks earlier Messi had provided the killer ball at Stamford Bridge that allowed Andres Iniestaâs sensational tie-winning leveller and sank Guus Hiddinkâs Blues on away goals.

Yet back then Messiâs zero goals against English clubs had led some bandwagon jumpers to doubt him.

So at the Stadio Olimpico against United geed-up Messi rose majestically to head Barcaâs second â a masterful finish across the face of Edwin Van Der Sarâs goal.

He has won the title of the best player in the world every year since that night.

Arsenal in the knockout stages and United, in last yearâs final at Wembley, have felt the full force of Messiâs killer instinct since that night in Rome.

Barca bid to reach a historic fifth semi on the bounce â and a third potentially against English opposition if Chelsea finish Benfica off tomorrow.

Guardiola said: âThe success we have is to be in the quarter-finals for the fifth consecutive time fighting to be in the semi-final of the European Cup.

"It is one of the things that makes me the most proud.â

Milanâs defensive machine has been boosted by the return of veteran star Alessandro Nesta since they dumped Arsenal out.

Last week with Nesta they shut Messi and Barcelona out.

Their boss Massimo Allegri knows Milan will go through with a score draw or a win â but they were practising pens yesterday, just in case it finishes goalless after extra time.

Allegri said: âBarcelona is the best team in the world and play the best football in the world.

"Milan has similar characteristics to Barcelona but certainly against them we have to play a different game.

âWe need to be careful and courageous. We need to score to go through.

"We will look to be positive knowing that we have two out of three results in our favour.

âItâs a historic game because it always is, because itâs between the two most important clubs.â

image.caption: ALL SMILES ... Barcelona's Lionel Messi in training yesterday

pages.subdeck: PRAY FOR MERCY ... City are growing tired of Mario Balotelli's antics
pages.headline: I won’t ditch Mario
pages.teaser: BUT the Man City boss has warned Balotelli he must buck his ideas up from now on
pages.articlebody:
ROBERTO MANCINI insists he will not give up on striker Mario Balotelli.

But the Manchester City boss has warned his fellow Italian he must buck up his ideas if he wants a big future at the Etihad.

SunSport revealed on Monday how the City squad are unhappy with the special treatment Balotelli gets from the manager.

City bigwigs are also growing increasingly tired and concerned by the 21-year-oldâs antics but Mancini has vowed to persevere with Super Mario, saying: âWill I give up on him? No. But I am frustrated.

âHe is young and I hope for him he can improve very quickly.

âSometimes I think it is not possible that a player with his class and technique can play a game like he did against Sunderland.â

City are not actively trying to sell Balotelli yet but are open-minded on what they would do if a big offer came in this summer.

The two Milan clubs are the most obvious destinations for the former Inter forward â who cost City Â£24million â if either can raise the funds.

His career at the Etihad is likely to hinge on how he performs and behaves during the last seven matches of the season.

It will also depend on whether Mancini is given the green light to continue this summer.

Balotelli has 17 goals in all competitions, the sixth-best record of any top-flight striker, but Mancini says it is not enough.

He added: âRight now it is important to have the strikers scoring important goals.

âA player like Mario, in the Premier League, should score one or two goals every game.

âMario only played well in the last five minutes against Sunderland and itâs not enough.â

Balotelli enraged some City fans when he rowed with Aleksandar Kolarov over who should take a free-kick during the 3-3 draw with Sunderland on Saturday.

There were also reports he had a dressing-room row with Yaya Toure, three weeks after they argued in the tunnel at Swansea.

Talking about the Kolarov row, Mancini said: âThat was bad. A professional player canât do what they did at 3-1 down.â

City skipper Vincent Kompany says the clubâs season will not be a failure even if they end it empty-handed.

Manciniâs men have surrendered the title advantage to Manchester United in the last three weeks.

Yet City look set for a top-two Premier League finish for the first time and have already equalled their best-ever points tally of 71.

Kompany, 25, said: âI joined the club three years ago and playing to win the league is a massive step forward.

âHopefully we can still win the title but, if not, weâll be there soon.â

article.caption: Wenger: Watch out City

pages.subdeck: SYMPTOMS ... Stiliyan Petrov
pages.headline: Pet’s Fab debt
pages.teaser: CANCER uncovered after Aston Villa ran tests following Fabrice Muamba’s collapse
pages.articlebody:
STILIYAN PETROVâS acute leukaemia was uncovered when the Aston Villa squad underwent heart tests after the collapse of Fabrice Muamba.

Villaâs Carlos Cuellar revealed: âLast Tuesday, after what happened to Muamba, experts came to our training ground to do tests on us and examine our hearts.

âTwo days later, we received the results and they communicated to Stan his symptoms of cancer.

âThey wanted him to go to hospital for more tests to confirm the original diagnosis.

âAt the beginning they didnât even tell him the truth directly and he didnât want to scare us either, with a game against Chelsea so close on Saturday.

âThey had told him âYes it could be cancer but we need to do more testsâ.

âSo he didnât tell anyone but itâs true his closest friends knew there was this possibility that it could be cancer.â

Petrov, 32, only told the whole of the Villa team once the news was confirmed on Friday.

It followed Bolton star Muambaâs cardiac arrest on the pitch against Tottenham on March 17.

Cuellar, in an interview with Spanish radio station COPE, added: âThe truth is we are very much affected by the very bad news about our captain.

âNo one expected it, it caught us by surprise and left us in shock.

âLast week we were still affected by the situation of Fabrice Muamba â it affected us mentally and psychologically.

âSo imagine if it is one of your intimate friends, a comrade with whom youâve shared a dressing room for four years.

âMy team-mates and I are deeply affected and very emotional but Stiliyan is the first to give us strength, trying to lift us so that we win as many games and points as we can.

âItâs the only thing he asked of us.â

Cuellar also revealed that Petrov still SINGS to him on the phone, a sign the brave Bulgarian is full of belief he will win his fight against illness.

Spanish defender Cuellar, 30, said: âHe always sings a song to me âCarlos Cuellar you make me happyâ.

âYesterday he surprised me because, when I called, he responded and started singing that song.

âIt relaxes you and it shows he will win this fight because heâs a brave man with a lot of strength.â

Alex McLeishâs Villa are having a tough time of it in the Premier League and lie just five points off the drop zone.

Yet Cuellar insists Petrov faces a much bigger fight â and has backed him to win it.

He added: âI speak to Stan every day and it is him that is giving us strength.

âHe knows itâs a tough situation but heâs certain he will win â and his family is giving him strength.

âHis first priority is to keep his wife and kids happy and recover as quickly as possible for them.

âHeâs a strong guy and he will definitely pull through.

âHeâs also a courageous man and knows he can give courage to many other people who are suffering the same fate.

âOften we seem like gods, untouchables but weâre normal â with the same weaknesses as everyone else.â

Petrov was fighting back tears as Villa Park rose to acclaim him during the clash with Chelsea.

Cuellar concluded: âHeâs getting countless messages of support from so many people.

âHeâs always had a smile on his face and he wants to continue smiling.â

pages.subdeck: ASH ON THE LASH ... Ashley Young seals victory with a stunning strike
pages.headline: Blackburn 0 Manchester United 2
pages.teaser: LATE goals from Valencia and Young saw Manchester United open up a five-point lead
pages.articlebody:
FOR Manchester Unitedâs fans it is now not if, but when.

The Blue faithful can only hope that it does not come at the Etihad on April 30.

That derby date was the one the noisy neighbours had been looking at to really lift the roof.

But in the blink of an eye the dream has faded and almost died.

Last night Manchester Unitedâs triumph at Ewood Park completed a 10-point swing in a month.

A spectacular strike from Antonio Valencia in the 81st minute followed by Ashley Youngâs turn and drive five minutes later sealed the victory.

As the seconds ticked down, the 7,000 travelling fans in the Darwen End called out âFergie give us a waveâ.

Alex Ferguson did more than that. He turned to them and punched the air with both fists.

It was as big a celebratory gesture as we have seen from the United boss all season.

He knew what last night meant and another managerial master class is almost complete.

From five points behind on March 3 to five points ahead a month later.

By the time City play Arsenal at the Emirates on Sunday afternoon it could be eight points.

Even Roberto Mancini conceded that would be that.

While City have stumbled, taking just five points from their last 12, United have stormed past them on a run of 10 wins and one draw.

For the third season running a trip to Ewood Park looks like proving decisive.

Two seasons ago a goalless draw here on the back of a home defeat to Chelsea would ultimately cost them the title.

Last season Wayne Rooneyâs penalty sealed a point in the penultimate game as a record 19th league title was won.

Last night it was moments of magic from Valencia and Young coupled with some brilliance from goalkeeper David De Gea and that unshakeable will and belief that saw United through.

First, Valenciaâs goal.

He was fed down the right by Rafael and then darted into the box on an angle.

Everyone waited for the pass, instead came the shot with the outside of his boot across and beyond the grasping clutch of Paul Robinson.

Fergie jumped from the bench, arms waving in excitement.

It says everything about the man that these moments still bring as much joy today as they ever have.

The second goal followed five minutes later and came at the end of two minutes of United possession and 38 passes.

It ended with Valenica squaring the final ball for Young.

In a blur he turned and shot, the ball starting its journey outside the right-hand upright but curling into the bottom corner.

That was that.

Yet it had been far from an easy night, despite United having the weight of the possession.

For De Gea it was the night his season turned full circle. On New Yearâs Eve his gaffe gifted Blackburn victory at Old Trafford and he was dropped.

Last night he made three world-class saves from Junior Hoilett, Marcus Olsson and Grant Hanley.

The supporters were singing De Geaâs name and you not would have put money on that at the turn of the year.

United had their chances in the first half too with Javier Hernandez miscuing an early chance and then clipping the ball off the post.

The second half brought opportunities at either end.

Morten Gamst Pedersen thought he had taken the lead for the home side until his 63rd-minute âgoalâ was ruled out after the assistant referee said the ball had gone out before Steven Nzonzi pulled it back.

Then in the 77th minute came a tackle that would prove as crucial as Valenciaâs goal at the other end. Hoilett broke to the byline and crossed, Yakubu was in at the near post and the Rovers fans behind the goal were already out of their seats.

But Rio Ferdinand got his foot in and executed a brilliant challenge.

Then the big moment came from Valencia and just five minutes after that Young scored.

Not only did the victory send United clear at the top but it dropped Rovers back into the bottom three on goal difference from QPR.

At the final whistle the United players and staff saluted the travelling fans, who had sang their hearts out all night.

âWeâre gonna win the leagueâ was their final refrain.

And few now would argue.

DREAM TEAM

STAR MAN â ANTONIO VALENCIA (MAN UNITED)

BLACKBURN: Robinson 6, Lowe 6, Dann 7, Hanley 7, Mt Olsson 7, Orr 6, Pedersen 6, Nzonzi 7, Mc Olsson 7, Hoilett 7, Yakubu 6. Subs not used: Bunn, Dunn, Modeste, Formica, Petrovic, Rochina, Henley. Booked: Hanley.

MAN UNITED: De Gea 8, Rafael 6, Evans 6, Ferdinand 7, Evra 6, Carrick 6, Scholes 7, Jones 6, Valencia 8, Hernandez 6, Rooney 7. Subs: Welbeck (Hernandez 61) 5, Giggs (Jones 63) 6, Young (Scholes 80) 6. Not used: Amos, Smalling, Park, Pogba. Booked: Valencia.

REF: H Webb 6

pages.subdeck: WORK OF VAART ... Van der Vaart hails his Sunday goal
pages.headline: Squeaky Gun time
pages.teaser: TOTTENHAM’S Dutch megastar reckons Arsenal will now be feeling the pressure
pages.articlebody:
RAFAEL VAN DER VAART cranked up the heat in the North London duel for third spot by insisting: Itâs squeaky Gun time.

Tottenhamâs Dutch master reckons Arsenal will now be feeling the pressure after another dramatic weekend.

Van der Vaart helped stuttering Spurs beat Swansea 3-1 at White Hart Lane on Sunday to go back level with the Gunners â after Arsene Wengerâs side suffered a shock 2-1 defeat at struggling QPR on Saturday.

Arsenal remain in third on goal difference, with just ONE GOAL separating the rivals.

Van der Vaart, whose Spurs side were 12 points ahead of their neighbours at the start of February, said: âI hope Arsenal are getting nervous. Itâs a big battle â Chelsea also keep winning â and itâs not going to be easy to lead from the front.

âIâm confident we can finish third. But I said a few weeks ago 12 points is a lot and we were going to stay in third!

âWe want to have Champions League again because last season it was a great experience. Itâs important we finish third not fourth because in qualifying there are some big teams and you never know what can happen.â

The Premâs top four go into the Champions League but the team in fourth face a qualifier before the group stage.

But even that chance could be blown out of the water if Chelsea win this seasonâs Champions League. That will earn Blues a place in next yearâs tournament, leaving the fourth-placed Prem team to face the delights of the Europa League.

While Arsenal must play Manchester City and Chelsea in their last seven matches, Tottenham face none of the big clubs in their run-in.

Striker Van der Vaart said: âYes we feel like we have the advantage. But sometimes we do better against the big teams.â

Van der Vaart scored Tottenhamâs opener against Swansea as they sealed their first league win in six matches.

And he said: âWe were a little low on confidence but we showed weâre still there and want to be in the top three.

âThereâs still a long way to go but confidence is back.â

Even Arsenal striker ROBIN VAN PERSIE admits they must beat Manchester City on Sunday to hang on to third.

Arsenal have a tough run-in and face Chelsea later this month after City.

Van Persie said: âThe next one is a big one against City. If we want third we have to beat them. Itâs as simple as that.

âWe have seven games left and playing big-name teams like City and Chelsea are games I like to play in as a fan of football. It wonât be easy, everyone is fighting for every point.â

pages.subdeck: CROCKED ... Wolves midfielder Jamie O'Hara
pages.headline: Jamie 'n Jody injuries hit Wolves
pages.teaser: WOLVES' hopes of beating the drop have been hit by a double injury blow
pages.articlebody:
WOLVES' hopes of beating the drop have been hit by a double blow.

Midfielder Jamie O'Hara and defender Jody Craddock could miss the rest of the season.

O'Hara has undergone surgery on the groin injury which has sidelined him since the home defeat to Blackburn over three weeks ago.

Meanwhile, Craddock has also gone under the knife in a bid to cure a long-standing hamstring problem.

Former Tottenham man O'Hara is expected to miss between six and eight weeks while the club predict Craddock will be out for at least five.

pages.subdeck: SMILES BETTER ... Branislav Ivanovic celebrates No 2 at Villa
pages.headline: Heat’s off says Bran
pages.teaser: DEFENDER says Blues can shock Champs League rivals as no one expects them to win
pages.articlebody:
CHELSEAâS Branislav Ivanovic reckons the heat is off in the Champions League â because, for once, they are not expected to win it.

The Blues face Benfica at Stamford Bridge tomorrow aiming to book a semi-final showdown against either Barcelona or AC Milan.

Roberto Di Matteoâs side take a 1-0 lead into the game. But after a controversial season, Ivanovic hinted expectation is lower this time around.

The Serbian defender, 28, said: âIf people think like that, it can be good for us because we will feel less pressure, which in games like this can be very important.

âBut Wednesday is a huge game for us. Itâs a big opportunity. We got a great result in Lisbon, but itâs not over because they donât have anything to lose.

âThey played very well in the first game so itâll be difficult. We have to be careful.â

And Ivanovic believes Saturdayâs 4-2 win at Aston Villa will act as a wake-up call going into the Benfica clash.

Chelsea eased into a two-goal lead before switching off and allowing Villa to level before stepping up again to win.

Ivanovic, who scored twice, added: âPsychologically that was good for us. It gave us something, which was great.

âWhen you are 2-0 up and in control, maybe you start to think about the next game. We lost concentration.

âWe made hard work of beating Villa but it was a really important win at the start of a big week, for sure.â

Interim boss Di Matteo said: âWeâve put ourselves in a good position, but Benfica away from home are a very strong side and they are capable of scoring as well so there will be no complacency at all.

âI think weâve been fighting very well in the last three weeks, weâve shown that on several occasions.â

Benfica will consider playing midfielder Javi Garcia at centre-half due to a defensive crisis.

Brazilian Jardel is the Portuguese sideâs biggest worry, with Miguel Vitor and Ezequiel Garay due to be sidelined.

pages.subdeck: UNMOVED ... Andrew Strauss
pages.headline: He’s still No1
pages.teaser: STRAUSS’ position as England Test skipper is in doubt after four defeats
pages.articlebody:
DARREN GOUGH insists England should never sack Andrew Strauss as skipper.

Under-fire Strauss has hit just ONE century in his last 48 innings as opener.

His position as Test skipper is also in doubt after four straight defeats.

Alastair Cook, 27, who captains the one-day team, has been tipped to be fast-tracked into the role as a successor to 35-year-old Strauss.

But former England paceman Gough says Strauss has stockpiled a gold bullion supply of credit thanks to his Ashes triumphs and leading England to the world No 1 spot.

Gough said: âIt will be Straussâ decision if he walks away and not anybody elseâs. He wonât, and should not, really ever lose his position as captain.

âHe has enough points in the bag to remain in charge this summer in the Test series against West Indies and South Africa.

âHeâs earned that right because of what he has achieved as a player and captain over a number of years.

âIf his low scores continue and team continue to under-perform, then Strauss will be brave enough to make his own mind up and step aside to let Cooky take over.But he should not pay the price as he is still the best man to take England forward.â

Gough says Englandâs place as No 1 will be over unless the batsmen rethink their strategy on the subcontinent â starting against Sri Lanka in the Second Test in Colombo today.

He added: âThe same mistakes are happening with shot selections and some batsman, especially Kevin Pietersen and Ian Bell, are living on borrowed time.â

This season, Darren Gough will be hosting a monthly magazine show called Goughie's LV= County Catch-Up. The first show will be hosted on www.facebook.com/englandcricket Tuesday 3rd April, 8pm

article.caption: Only Strauss himself will make the call to quit
Durham sign up Aussie Johnson

pages.subdeck: FINN IT TO WIN IT ... Kimi Raikkonen
pages.headline: Kimi: I can fight at the front
pages.teaser: KIMI RAIKKONEN reckons his Lotus is good enough to challenge the leading pack
pages.articlebody:
BORN-AGAIN Kimi Raikkonen reckons his Lotus is good enough to fight at the front â even though he has not been able to prove it.

The 2007 world champ, back in Formula 1 after two years of rallying, has shown flashes of world-beating speed.

And his team-mate Romain Grosjean has done the same.

But Raikkonen has been compromised by being knocked out of qualifying early in Australia and copping a penalty for a gearbox change in Malaysia.

Grosjean crashed out in both races without being able to show his potential.

But âIcemanâ Raikkonen insisted: âI think we've got off to an encouraging start.

âIt has been frustrating sometimes but we've shown we can deal with problems and come back stronger.

âThe car feels good and we clearly have the pace to be at the front. We just need some better luck."

Raikkonen said he feels like he has never been away from F1.

He added: "Maybe people see me as more relaxed, which I think is down to the team.

"It's a different atmosphere to what I've experienced before. Everyone is very open and laid back but at the same time they work extremely hard and pay a lot of attention to detail.

"I feel comfortable here, which helps me to focus on racing. I guess that's why people seem to think I'm a different person. But I'm just as focused and motivated as before."

Lotusâs trackside chief Alan Permane backed Raikkonen â and believes the team will emerge as F1âs third best, ready to take the fight to McLaren and Red Bull.

He said: "It would be nice to have a straightforward race with no penalties and no crashes from Romain after the first couple of corners.

âI think it is McLaren and Red Bull Racing at the front, and then I believe we are there.

âIt's going to be a good battle. To be in a development race with these proper big boys means it will take everything we've got to stay with them."

article.caption: Jet lag is bad snooze for our truckies

image.caption: FINN IT TO WIN IT ... Kimi Raikkonen

pages.subdeck: GOLDEN BROWN ... St Helens have confirmed Nathan Brown as their new coach
pages.headline: Brown in Giant leap to Saints
pages.teaser: NATHAN BROWN has been confirmed as the new coach of St Helens on a three-year contract
pages.articlebody:
NATHAN BROWN has been confirmed as the new coach of St Helens on a three-year contract from the start of next season.

The Huddersfield boss, 38, will replace Royce Simmons in the hotseat at Langree Park.

Brown said: âItâs an honour to be appointed the head coach of St Helens.

"They are a great and historic club and continuously associated with success; Iâm relishing the challenge for next season onwards.

"They have a strong first team squad and more promising youngsters coming through their system, along with a great new stadium and training facility.

âThat said, this season is all about Huddersfield Giants for me and itâs good to get this announcement out of the way so that I can concentrate totally on the job at hand.â

Brown has impressed since arriving in Super League in 2009 when lead the Giants to the Challenge Cup final in his first season.

He transformed Huddersfield from a bottom-three team to consistent play-off performers.

The Giants finished third in 2009, fifth in 2010 and fourth last season, although they lost to champions Leeds in the preliminary semi-finals.

Brown's appointment at Saints was one of the worst-kept secrets in rugby league after Simmons' exit last month.

Since then, they have had an upturn in form with two comprehensive wins over Leeds and Warrington to get their season back on track.

Saints chairman Eamonn McManus said: âWe are extremely pleased that Nathan will be joining us next season.

"I believe he is ideally suited for the Saints both with regard to the way we want to play and as to what we aim to achieve in terms of success.

âHe is still a relatively young coach but already has pedigree and experience gained over many years as a head coach at the highest levels both in the NRL and in Super League.â

image.caption: GOLDEN BROWN ... St Helens have confirmed Nathan Brown as their new coach
